<chapter>
<metadata.block><metadata field="right.running.head"><value>Social and Recreation</value></metadata></metadata.block>
<front>
<outline.name.block><label>Chapter</label><designator>30</designator><name>Social and Recreation</name></outline.name.block>
<scope.statement.block>
<para><para.text>This chapter contains forms for use in the formation, management, and dissolution or winding up of social and recreational associations and not-for-profit corporations established for social and/or recreational purposes. Also included is a discussion of legal principles, including tax aspects, that should be considered when drafting such documents.</para.text></para>
</scope.statement.block>
<treated.elsewhere.block>
<para><para.text>Charities and foundations, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="31:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;31:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<para><para.text>Cooperatives, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="32:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;32:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<para><para.text>Corporations, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="17:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;17:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<para><para.text>Joint ventures, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="19:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;19:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<para><para.text>Professional service corporations, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="17A:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;17A:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
</treated.elsewhere.block>

<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:1</designator><name>In general</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="101 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>Social and recreational organizations may be formed either as unincorporated associations or clubs or as not-for-profit corporations. Both types of organizations serve primarily the same purpose and function. A not-for-profit corporation, however, is subject to greater statutory regulation.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="101 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;101 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nature of associations and clubs, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1 et seq." secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;1 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="9 to 13" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;9 to 13</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Definition, nature, and kinds of associations and clubs, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1 to 3" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;1 to 3</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>Members&apos; rights will be much the same whether a social or recreational organization takes the form of a corporation or an association. Membership in the club may be accorded or withheld on such terms and conditions as the organization sees fit to impose. The bylaws and regulations may provide for the requirements of eligibility as a member as well as the admission, rights, interests, and privileges of members. The power to regulate membership will exist regardless of whether the organization is formed as an unincorporated association<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Rights and liabilities arising out of contract for lifetime membership in social or fraternal club or association" volref="10" pageref="1357">Rights and liabilities arising out of contract for lifetime membership in social or fraternal club or association, 10 A.L.R.3d 1357</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Regulation of membership in association, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="15 to 24" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;15 to 24</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Members of not-for-profit corporations, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="822 to 838" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;822 to 838</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> or as a not-for-profit corporation.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;601 et seq.</cite></para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>Fees, dues, and assessments may be enforced and collected from the members of either type of organization in accordance with the provisions of the governing instruments.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Liability for dues and assessments, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="19">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;19</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Fees, dues, and assessments in not-for-profit corporations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="828, 829" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;828, 829</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>On a member&apos;s acceptance of membership in a social or recreational organization, the basic laws and regulations of the organization become a binding contract between the member and the organization.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4 to 8" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;4 to 8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|1|30:1"><para.text>This chapter deals primarily with not-for-profit associations that are organized for social and recreational purposes. However, much of the discussion applies to associations organized for other not-for-profit purposes.</para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>B</designator><name>Tax Aspects</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>1</designator><name>General Considerations</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:2</designator><name>Qualifying for tax-exempt status</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Internal Revenue" numref="4045 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Nonprofit organizations are often exempt from federal and state income taxation. However, exemption is not granted merely because an organization is nonprofit. The organization must be of a type that can qualify for exemptions under federal and state law, and it must take the necessary procedural steps to establish these exemptions.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>For practical information concerning the rules and procedures for organizations that seek recognition of exemption from federal income tax under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(a)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(a)</cite>, see <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-pub" numref="557">I.R.S. Pub. 557</cite>, &ldquo;Tax-Exempt Status for Your Organization.&rdquo;</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>For discussion of tax-exempt organizations, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:53 et seq." secrange="y">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-irc" titleref="26" secref="501">Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code</cite> lists the types of organizations that can qualify for exemption. The more common organizations granted exempt status include those considered altruistic in nature.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:53 to 10:79" secrange="y">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 to 10:79</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> These include religious, educational, scientific, and literary organizations. Less altruistic, but nevertheless community-minded, are such associations as civic leagues, labor unions, chambers of commerce, business associations, credit unions, cemetery companies, veterans&apos; associations, and social clubs.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Most of these are listed in <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)</cite>; other exempt organizations may be found in <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(d), (f)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(d), (f)</cite> and <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="526 to 528" secrange="y">26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;526 to 528</cite>. Farmers&apos; cooperatives are covered by <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="521" subref="(a)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;521(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:53 to 10:79" secrange="y">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 to 10:79</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Each type of organization must meet its own requirements for exemption. A church, for example, cannot participate in a political campaign and no substantial part of its activities can be expended to influence legislation.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Political activities, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:92">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:92</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> A social club cannot discriminate in membership because of race, color, or religion and must limit membership and public access.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(i)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> Other exempt organizations must comply with their own requirements.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>In general, exempt organizations must meet two sets of tests: organizational and operational. The organizations under Section 501(c)(3) may be used as an example. Section 501(c)(3) includes religious, charitable, scientific, testing for public safety, literary, or educational organizations.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Anticruelty societies and certain sports organizations are also covered.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:81">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:81</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The charter documents of these organizations must limit the organization&apos;s purpose to one or more of the purposes listed in the Code. The powers cannot extend to other activities. The charter cannot empower the organization to devote more than an insubstantial part of its activities to influencing legislation or otherwise intervening in any political campaign for a candidate to public office.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Political activities, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:92">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:92</cite>. Organizations engaged in influencing legislation are not engaged in an exempt activity. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(3)-1" subref="(c)" pararef="(3)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(3)</cite>. They may, however, qualify as a social welfare organization under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(4)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(4)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> The charter must provide that the earnings shall not inure to the benefit of any private person. It must also provide that on dissolution the assets be distributed for exempt or public purposes.<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="501(c)(3)-1" subref="(b)" pararef="(4)">26 C.F.R. &sect;501(c)(3)-1(b)(4)</cite>. The charter need not contain this provision if state law requires distribution for exempt purposes.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Private benefit rules, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:88">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:88</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> If an entity is organized to carry on a trade or business, it cannot be exempt, even if all profits are payable to an exempt organization.<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="502" subref="(a)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;502(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Form of organization, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:54">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:54</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> To satisfy the operational test, the organization must engage primarily in activities that further its exempt purpose. Only an insubstantial portion of its activities can be devoted to activities not in furtherance of that purpose.<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(3)-1" subref="(c)" pararef="(1)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(3)-1(c)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:56">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> No part of its net earnings may inure to the benefit of private individuals, and it cannot engage in propaganda or other political activities.<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>An exception exists for elections by organizations (other than churches and private foundations) to make certain limited lobbying expenditures. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(h)-2" subref="(a)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(h)-2(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Political activities, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:92">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:92</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Incorporation is not required for most exempt organizations. For example, exemptions may be obtained by civic leagues or organizations not organized for profit<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(4)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(4)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> and by insurance companies or associations.<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(15)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(15)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:56">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> A credit union must be without capital stock.<footnote><footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(14)" spararef="(A)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(14)(A)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> On the other hand, exempt title holding companies must be corporations,<footnote><footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(2)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(2)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> as must be farmers&apos; crop financing cooperatives.<footnote><footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(16)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(16)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Exempt purposes, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:56">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:56</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Here again, the exact requirements for an organization must be met.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>In general, the exemption extends to social and recreational clubs that are supported solely by membership fees, dues, and assessments.<footnote><footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(7)-1" subref="(a)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(7)-1(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:75">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> However, a club that engages in business, such as making its social and recreational facilities available to the general public or by selling real estate, timber, or other products, is not organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes and is not exempt under the Code.<footnote><footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(7)-1" subref="(b)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(7)-1(b)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>The articles of association or incorporation and bylaws are of importance in determining the exempt status of an organization. They must provide the purposes and powers necessary to qualify the organization as exempt, and they may not contain any additional power or purpose that would render the organization nonexempt.<footnote><footnote.reference>19</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="case">Sun-Herald Corporation v. Duggan, 73 F.2d 298 (C.C.A. 2d Cir. 1934)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Charters, bylaws, and other enabling documents, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:55">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:55</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>A club organized for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes is not exempt from taxation for any taxable year if, at any time during such taxable year, the charter, bylaws, or other governing instrument of the organization or any written policy statement of the organization contains a provision that provides for discrimination against any person on the basis of race, color, or religion.<footnote><footnote.reference>20</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(i)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> This federal prohibition of discrimination by certain social clubs does not apply to an auxiliary of a fraternal benefit society meeting certain requirements, which limits its membership to the members of a particular religion,<footnote><footnote.reference>21</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(i)" pararef="(1)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> or to a club that in good faith limits its membership to the members of a particular religion in order to further the teachings or principles of that religion and not to exclude individuals of a particular race or color.<footnote><footnote.reference>22</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(i)" pararef="(2)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)(2)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Although the organization must be organized and operated exclusively for nonprofitable purposes, a club otherwise entitled to exemption will not be disqualified because it raises revenue from members through the use of club facilities or in connection with club activities<footnote><footnote.reference>23</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(7)-1" subref="(a)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(7)-1(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:75">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> or by an incidental sale of property.<footnote><footnote.reference>24</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(7)-1" subref="(b)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(7)-1(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:75">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>On the other hand, a club that opens its social and recreational facilities to the general public on a large enough scale or that solicits public use by advertising may lose its exemption. Where there is no solicitation, the principal factor in determining exempt status is the extent of outside use. If the club earns more than the amount permitted under federal guidelines, a decision as to whether substantially all of its activities are related to its exempt purposes is based on all the facts and circumstances. In such a case, the organization is taxed as a business enterprise and entitled to all the deductions and tax benefits of such enterprise.<footnote><footnote.reference>25</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="case">U.S. v. Fort Worth Club of Fort Worth, Tex., 348 F.2d 891 (5th Cir. 1965)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:75">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Solicitation by advertisement or otherwise for public patronage of the club&apos;s facilities is prima facie evidence that the club is engaging in business and is not being operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation, or social purposes.<footnote><footnote.reference>26</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(c)(7)-1" subref="(b)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(c)(7)-1(b)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Investment income of exempt organizations not derived from controlled corporations, including all dividends, interest, payments with respect to securities loans, and annuities, royalties, and certain rents, is generally exempt from taxation.<footnote><footnote.reference>27</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512" subref="(b)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Such income is subject to the tax on unrelated business income if derived from controlled corporations. See <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:5">&sect;30:5</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:59">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Dividends, interest, and royalties, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:68">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:68</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Other investment income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:70">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:70</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Rents, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:71">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:71</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> However, certain income received by exempt organizations from or on account of debt-financed property is subject to tax on unrelated business income. Tax is imposed on the amount of such income which is the same percentage (but not in excess of 100&percnt;) of total gross income derived during the taxable year from the property as the average acquisition indebtedness is of the average amount of the adjusted basis.<footnote><footnote.reference>28</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(a)" pararef="(1)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(a)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Debt-financed acquisitions, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:77, 10:78" secrange="y">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:77, 10:78</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Also excluded are all gains on the lapse or termination of options written by the organization in connection with its investment activities to buy or sell securities, except with respect to the cutting of timber.<footnote><footnote.reference>29</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512" subref="(b)" pararef="(5)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)(5)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:59">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>While investment by the exempt organization of its principal and income in realty, personal property, or securities will not ordinarily deprive the organization of its exemption, the exemption may be lost if the investment activities constitute a trade or business.<footnote><footnote.reference>30</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="case">Randall Foundation, Inc. v. Riddell, 244 F.2d 803 (9th Cir. 1957)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:59">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:59</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Certain tax-exempt organizations may pool investment funds through a tax-exempt corporation or trust to invest in real estate. The corporation or trust must, among other requirements, have no more than 35 shareholders or beneficiaries, have one class of stock or beneficial interest, and be organized for the exclusive purpose of acquiring property and holding title to, and collecting income from, such property, and remitting the entire amount of income from such property (less expenses) to shareholders or beneficiaries.<footnote><footnote.reference>31</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(25)" spararef="(A)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(25)(A)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> An organization applies for an exemption by submitting a cover letter, indicating that it is applying for an exemption under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-irc" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(25)">Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(25)</cite>, and submitting Form 1024, providing all information on Schedule A (including the basis for shareholders&apos; or beneficiaries&apos; eligibility).</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>A not-for-profit corporation is exempt from state corporation franchise taxes, except as to any unrelated business tax income of the organization,<footnote><footnote.reference>32</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>As to state and federal taxation of unrelated business taxable income, generally, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:5">&sect;30:5</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> if the corporation does not have any stock or shares or other certificates of ownership interests, the corporation is operated on a not-for-profit basis, and no part of the corporation&apos;s net earnings inure to the benefit of any officer, director, or member.<footnote><footnote.reference>33</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-ny-ccr" titleref="20" secref="1-2.11" subref="(b)" pararef="(6)">20 NYCRR &sect;1-2.11(b)(6)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-tax" secref="209">NYTL &sect;209</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Under New York law, not-for-profit corporations are prohibited from having stock or shares or certificates for stock or for shares, though they may issue nontransferable membership certificates or cards to evidence membership. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="501">N-PCL &sect;501</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Statutory assessment on gross receipts of residential health care facilities was not &ldquo;franchise tax,&rdquo; from which charitable organizations were exempt, and thus assessment did not violate state constitutional provision barring repeal of charitable tax exemptions; assessment was not imposed on facilities&apos; net income, and there was no statutory prohibition on imposition of gross receipts tax. <cite type="case">Charles T. Sitrin Health Care Center, Inc. v. State of New York, 195 Misc. 2d 824, 761 N.Y.S.2d 452 (Sup 2003)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> Not-for-profit corporations are also exempt from the New York City franchise tax to the extent their activities do not generate a profit.<footnote><footnote.reference>34</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-ny-ccr" titleref="20" secref="1-2.11" subref="(b)" pararef="(6)">20 NYCRR &sect;1-2.11(b)(6)</cite>; <cite type="case">Pan American Athletic &amp; Social Club, Inc. v. Commissioner of Finance of City of New York, 94 A.D.2d 606, 461 N.Y.S.2d 1017 (1st Dep&apos;t 1983)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Not-for-profit corporations that meet statutory or regulatory requirements also are specifically exempted from having to pay New York State and city sales or use taxes.<footnote><footnote.reference>35</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-tax" secref="1116" subref="(a)" pararef="(4)">NYTL &sect;1116(a)(4)</cite>; <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-ny-ccr" titleref="20" secref="529.7">20 NYCRR &sect;529.7</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr5" titlename="Exemption of charitable or educational organization from sales or use tax" volref="69" pageref="477">Exemption of charitable or educational organization from sales or use tax, 69 A.L.R.5th 477</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Exemption of religious organization from sales or use tax" volref="54" pageref="1204">Exemption of religious organization from sales or use tax, 54 A.L.R.3d 1204</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The corporation is also exempt from the New York City vault tax,<footnote><footnote.reference>36</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-nyc-admincode" secref="11-2703" subref="(4)">New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2703(4)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> commercial rent tax,<footnote><footnote.reference>37</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-nyc-admincode" secref="11-704" subref="(a)" pararef="(4)">New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-704(a)(4)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> vehicle owner&apos;s tax,<footnote><footnote.reference>38</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-nyc-admincode" secref="11-2203" subref="(6)">New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2203(6)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> hotel room occupancy tax,<footnote><footnote.reference>39</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-nyc-admincode" secref="11-2502" subref="(e)">New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2502(e)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> retail liquor licensee tax,<footnote><footnote.reference>40</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-nyc-admincode" secref="11-2403" subref="(d)">New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-2403(d)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> taxicab license transfer tax,<footnote><footnote.reference>41</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-nyc-admincode" secref="11-1405" subref="(a)" pararef="(4)">New York City Administrative Code &sect;11-1405(a)(4)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> and utility tax.<footnote><footnote.reference>42</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-tax" secref="1230" subref="(d)">NYTL &sect;1230(d)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text>Although tax-exempt, most organizations must file an annual information return and are subject to a penalty tax for failure to file.<footnote><footnote.reference>43</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="6652">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;6652</cite>. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-form" numref="990">IRS Form 990</cite> is used for this. If the exempt organization is a private foundation (discussed later), the form is 990-PF.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> Churches and certain other exempt entities are exempt from this requirement. All exempt organizations must file information returns on business payments of &dollar;600 or more, on tax withheld, on cash receipts of &dollar;10,000 or more, and on payments of dividends and interest.<footnote><footnote.reference>44</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="6041">26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;6041</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="6042">6042</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="6050I">6050I</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> They must also report dispositions of donated property that occur within two years after receipt of the property.<footnote><footnote.reference>45</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|2|30:2"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.6050L-1" subref="(f)" pararef="(2)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.6050L-1(f)(2)</cite>. The form is 8282.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:3</designator><name>Qualifying for tax-exempt status<sep/>Obtaining exempt status; federal and state</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Internal Revenue" numref="4045 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>As stated earlier, an organization does not generally enjoy an exemption from federal income tax merely because it is not organized and operated for profit. In order to establish its exempt status, every such organization claiming an exemption must file an application form with the appropriate office as designated by the Commissioner in guidance published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin, forms, or instructions to the applicable forms.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(a)-1" subref="(a)" pararef="(2)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(a)-1(a)(2)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-4000 et seq." parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-4000 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> When an exempt and unincorporated association is incorporated, a new legal entity is created and a new application for exemption is necessary, even though the new corporation merely continues its previous activities. An organization seeking exemption under Section 501(c)(3) of the Code, which covers most exempt organizations, must apply for exemption within 15 months after organization.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.508-1" subref="(a)" pararef="(2)" spararef="(i)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.508-1(a)(2)(i)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Application for exempt status, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:57">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:57</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>To obtain exemption, a written application must be filed, even where no official forms are provided; oral requests for exemption will not be considered. Official application forms are provided as follows:<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Certain organizations do not file an official form. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-pub" numref="557">I.R.S. Pub. 557</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><ital>Form 1023:</ital> Religious, charitable, scientific, literary, educational, etc., organizations described in Section 501(c)(3) of the Code;<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(3)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>See also <cite type="case">National Paralegal Inst. Coalition v. C.I.R., T.C. Memo. 2005-293, T.C.M. (RIA) P 2005-293 (2005)</cite>, where the Service reviews procedural aspects of filing Form 1023.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> public safety testing; fostering certain amateur sports competition; prevention of cruelty to children or animals; educational organizations&apos; cooperative service organizations; and cooperative hospital service organizations.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><ital>Form 1024:</ital> Used by title holding companies,<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(2)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(2)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> civic leagues, social welfare organizations, and local associations of employees;<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(4)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(4)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> labor, agricultural or horticultural organizations;<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(5)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(5)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> business leagues or chambers of commerce;<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(6)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(6)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> social clubs;<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(7)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(7)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Social and recreational clubs, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:75">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:75</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> fraternal societies, orders, or associations;<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(8) or (10)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(8) or (10)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> voluntary employees&apos; beneficiaries associations;<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(9)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(9)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Voluntary Employee Benefit Associations (VEBAs), <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:76">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:76</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> benevolent life insurance associations; mutual ditch or irrigation companies; mutual or cooperative telephone companies or like organizations;<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(12)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(12)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> cemetery companies;<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(13)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(13)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> mutual insurance companies or associations other than life;<footnote><footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(15)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(15)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> supplemental unemployment benefit trusts;<footnote><footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(17)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(17)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> and by veterans&apos; organizations.<footnote><footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(c)" pararef="(19)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(c)(19)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>The official forms require detailed information peculiar to the type of organization seeking exemption. Where no official application form is provided, consult the local district director for the information to be submitted and the procedure to be followed in establishing the exemption.</para.text></para>
<feature.para.block><name.block><name>Practice Tip:</name></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Before preparing the application, obtain <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-pub" numref="557">I.R.S. Pub. 557</cite>, &ldquo;Tax-Exempt Status for Your Organization.&rdquo; The publication sets out the requirements for organizing and operating exempt organizations. The detailed qualifications for each type of exempt organization are discussed, as are the filing requirements.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>A power of attorney must be filed if the organization applying for the exemption expects to be represented in person or by correspondence by an agent or attorney. It is now possible to file the form electronically. The power must specifically authorize the agent or attorney to represent the organization before the Internal Revenue Service. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-form" numref="2848">IRS Form 2848</cite>, &ldquo;Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative,&rdquo; may be used for this purpose.<footnote><footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-pub" numref="557">I.R.S. Pub. 557</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</feature.para.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Conformed copies of each of the following must accompany the application:<footnote><footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-pub" numref="557">I.R.S. Pub. 557</cite>. Do not send original documents as the documents are retained in the IRS files and cannot be returned.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Articles or Certificate of Incorporation or trust instrument or other document setting forth the organization&apos;s authorized powers and purposes and any amendment of such document changing the name of the organization;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Bylaws or other similar code of regulations;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Financial statements showing receipts and expenditures for the current year and the three immediate prior years (or the years the organization was in existence, if less than four years). If the current year is less than a full year or if operations have not yet begun, a proposed budget for two full accounting periods and a current statement of assets and liabilities will be acceptable. Bank statements, ledger sheets, and profit and loss or similar operating statements that do not show all receipts and expenditures classified are not acceptable for this purpose;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>A statement of the proposed activities of the organization, if required by the application form; and</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Any additional information necessary to clarify the nature of the organization. This may consist of copies of advertising by the organization, magazines published by it, and written material used for the purpose of expressing views on proposed legislation.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>All attachments to the application should show the organization&apos;s name, address, and Employer Identification Number (EIN); the date; and a heading identifying the document and that it is an attachment to the exemption application.<footnote><footnote.reference>19</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-pub" numref="557">I.R.S. Pub. 557</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>In most cases, determination letters or rulings will be issued in advance of operation, provided the organization can describe its proposed operations in sufficient detail to convince the IRS that they will be clearly exempt under the law. A user fee must be paid for an exempt organization determination letter request. In this connection, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-form" numref="8718">IRS Form 8718</cite> must be attached to the determination letter application.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>A ruling of tax exemption may be retroactively revoked where a social club misrepresents or omits material facts from its exemption application, especially where they concern the financial status of the club.<footnote><footnote.reference>20</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="case">Colombo Club, Inc. v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 54 T.C. 100, 1970 WL 2397 (1970), decision aff&apos;d, 447 F.2d 1406 (9th Cir. 1971)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text>Once an organization has obtained its tax-exempt status at the federal level, it must also make application for such status in New York. To obtain an exemption, the corporation must file Form CT-247 and all IRS documents granting or denying an exemption with the Department of Taxation and Finance. The IRS determination is generally followed.<footnote><footnote.reference>21</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|3|30:3"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-ny-ccr" titleref="20" secref="1-2.11" subref="(b)" pararef="(6)">20 NYCRR &sect;1-2.11(b)(6)</cite></para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:4</designator><name>Qualifying for tax-exempt status<sep/>Revocation or modification of exempt status; related procedures</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Internal Revenue" numref="4045 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text>Federal rulings and determination letters granting exemption may be revoked or modified for such causes as a change in the law or regulations; substantial changes in the organization&apos;s character, purposes, or methods of operation;<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="1.501(a)-1" subref="(a)" pararef="(2)">26 C.F.R. &sect;1.501(a)-1(a)(2)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> the omission or misstatement by the organization of a material fact; engaging in a prohibited transaction entered into for the purpose of diverting the organization&apos;s corpus or income from its exempt purpose; and failure to file an annual information return. Rulings and determination letters granting exemption may be revoked retroactively and deficiencies and penalties may be claimed for open years. However, the Internal Revenue Service has generally limited retroactive revocation to cases where a material fact was omitted or misstated, the organization operated in a manner materially different from that represented, or the organization engaged in a prohibited transaction.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="601.201" subref="(n)" pararef="(6)">26 C.F.R. &sect;601.201(n)(6)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text>An organization may obtain an administrative review of the denial of its exemption application or of a proposed revocation or modification of its exemption by filing a timely protest. If the organization is unsuccessful and a deficiency is proposed, the organization may seek administrative and judicial review. An organization cannot enjoin an IRS revocation of its exemption while its status is being litigated; its proper remedy is to sue for refund of taxes.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text>The revocation will ordinarily take effect no later than the time at which the organization received written notice that its exemption ruling or determination letter might be revoked.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-cfr" titleref="26" secref="601.201" subref="(n)" pararef="(6)" spararef="(i)">26 C.F.R. &sect;601.201(n)(6)(i)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text>Formerly, if an exempt organization violated the rules prohibiting private benefit from its operations, the Service&apos;s only option as a sanction was to revoke the entity&apos;s exempt status. However, the Service now is allowed the imposition of so-called &ldquo;intermediate&rdquo; sanctions, pursuant to which the Service can, under Section 4958, impose monetary penalties in the form of excise taxes.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|4|30:4"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="4958">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;4958</cite>. See <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="31:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;31:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Excise taxes on excess benefit transactions, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-6650 et seq." parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-6650 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:5</designator><name>Taxation of unrelated business income</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Internal Revenue" numref="4045 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>A tax-exempt corporation is taxed on its unrelated business income; only income from its exempt function is nontaxable.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="511" subref="(a)" pararef="(1)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511(a)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Taxation of unrelated business income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-6800 et seq." parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-6800 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Exempt income is of two kinds. First is investment income: interest, dividends, royalties, real estate rentals.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512</cite>. Rentals from personal property are not exempt unless they are part of a real estate rental. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512" subref="(b)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)(3)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> Second are fees and other income from the operation of the exempt function of the organization. Taxable business income is therefore made up of income from any operations that are not the exempt business of the organization. Any business in which goods are sold or services are rendered is an unrelated business.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(c)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(c)</cite>. The share of gross income of a publicly traded partnership is also unrelated business income. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512" subref="(c)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Taxation of unrelated business income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-6800 et seq." parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-6800 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> However, unrelated business income is significantly different for clubs than for other exempt organizations.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>A special definition is provided by <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512" subref="(a)" pararef="(3)" spararef="(A)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(a)(3)(A)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> For a club, taxable income includes all income other than income from members. Other exempt organizations are taxed on gross income from an unrelated trade or business. After making certain adjustments in the way deductions are taken, the club&apos;s income is taxed at corporate rates.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="511" subref="(a)" pararef="(1)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;511(a)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Computing unrelated business income tax, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-6900 et seq." parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-6900 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>Three kinds of businesses are exempt from taxation as unrelated business income:<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(a)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(a)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>1</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>Businesses where all the work is done by volunteers without pay;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>2</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>Businesses carried on primarily for the convenience of patients or employees; and</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>3</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>Businesses that sell merchandise received as a donation.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>In addition, certain public entertainment activities and certain convention and trade show activities do not result in taxable income.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(d)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(d)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Qualified public entertainment activities, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-6840">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &para;D-6840</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Convention and trade show exception to unrelated trade or business rules for tax exempt organizations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-6841">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &para;D-6841</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Trade shows and conventions, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:61">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:61</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>Income earned from debt-financed property owned by an exempt organization is also unrelated business income.<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512" subref="(b)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;512(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Debt-financed income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-7000 et seq." parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-7000 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> This rule applies no matter what form the income may take. The amount taxed is based on the ratio of the average acquisition debt on the property to the adjusted basis of the property.<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(c)" pararef="(7)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(7)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Debt/basis gross income percentage for debt-financed property, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-7002">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &para;D-7002</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> This ratio is applied to the gross income from the property to calculate the amount of taxable income. The same percentage of expenses of the property is then deducted to determine net income.<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(a)" pararef="(1)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(a)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> The most obvious examples of debt-financed property are the acquisition of property subject to a mortgage and property purchased on an installment basis.<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(b)" pararef="(1)" spararef="(A)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(b)(1)(A)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text>Several kinds of acquisitions are exempt from the debt-financed property rule.<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(c)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Property excluded from debt-financed property under unrelated business income tax rules, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-7012 to D-7019" parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-7012 to D-7019</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> It does not apply to property donated to the organization as a gift.<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(c)" pararef="(2)" spararef="(B)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(2)(B)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Property excluded from debt-financed property under unrelated business income tax rules, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-7012 to D-7019" parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-7012 to D-7019</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> It also does not apply to property acquired for use in the exempt function of the organization, land acquired near the organization&apos;s other property, and certain property used for research. Furthermore, acquisition indebtedness does not include liabilities incurred by an employees&apos; pension plan or by an educational institution to acquire or improve real property.<footnote><footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|5|30:5"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="514" subref="(c)" pararef="(9)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;514(c)(9)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Property excluded from debt-financed property under unrelated business income tax rules, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftc2" parmkref="D-7012 to D-7019" parmkrange="y">RIA Federal Tax Coordinator 2d &dblpara;D-7012 to D-7019</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Various requirements attach in order for these exemptions to apply.</para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:6</designator><name>Internet activities taxable as unrelated business income</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Internal Revenue" numref="4045 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Internal Revenue &key;4045 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"><para.text>Activities that promote demand for industry products and services, like other advertising activities, generally would constitute a &ldquo;trade or business&rdquo; if carried on for the production of income. A narrow exception is provide as to what constitutes an &ldquo;unrelated trade or business.&rdquo;<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(d)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(d)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Internet activities taxable as unrelated business income, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:63">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &sect;10:63</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> For income received by a trade association or other nonprofit organization at its convention or trade show from renting display space may constitute unrelated business taxable income if selling by exhibitors is permitted or tolerated at the show.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"><para.text>The activities described in <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(d)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(d)(3)</cite> are specifically excepted from the definition of an unrelated trade or business because they are conducted by a qualifying organization in furtherance of its exempt purposes and in connection with a convention, annual meeting, or trade show. The terms &ldquo;convention, annual meeting, or trade show&rdquo; refer to a specific event at which individuals representing a particular industry and members of the general public gather in person at one location during a certain period of time. Not only must the activities be conducted at a convention, annual meeting, or trade show, but the character of the exhibits and the extent of the industry products displayed at the show must be designed to stimulate interest in, and demand for, the products and services of the industry in general or to educate persons in attendance regarding new developments or products and services related to the exempt activities of the organization. It is the nature of the activities and their connection to a specific convention, annual meeting, or trade show that distinguishes qualified convention and trade show activity.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(d)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(d)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> To clarify how Internet activities fit within the exception under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="513" subref="(d)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;513(d)(3)</cite>, the Service has provide guidance.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|6|30:6"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="exec-us-irs-ruling" numref="2004-112" volref="2004-51" reporter="I.R.B." volpg="985">Rev. Rul. 2004-112, 2004-51 I.R.B. 985</cite>.</para.text></para>
