<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>II</designator><name>Unincorporated Associations</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>A</designator><name>General Considerations</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>1</designator><name>Introduction</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:18</designator><name>Definition; general background</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="101 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>An unincorporated association is an organization consisting of a body of persons united without a charter for the prosecution of a common enterprise.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text><cite type="case">Heifetz v. Rockaway Point Volunteer Fire Dept., 124 N.Y.S.2d 257 (Sup 1953), order aff&apos;d, 282 A.D. 1062, 126 N.Y.S.2d 604 (2d Dep&apos;t 1953)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> An organization may be deemed to be an association as that term is used in the law, although it bears the name of a &ldquo;society,&rdquo; &ldquo;league,&rdquo; &ldquo;board,&rdquo; &ldquo;union,&rdquo; &ldquo;foundation,&rdquo; &ldquo;syndicate,&rdquo; or the like.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Definition of associations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;1</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Definition of associations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1 to 3" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;1 to 3</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="ftglf" secref="10:53 et seq." secrange="y">Federal Tax Guide to Legal Forms &dblsect;10:53 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>The term &ldquo;club&rdquo; includes bodies formed by the incorporation or association of persons for social purposes or for any common purpose other than pecuniary profit or benefit, and not of specifically educational, charitable, or religious nature. The term &ldquo;association&rdquo; is properly applied to an unincorporated society or body of individuals, formed for social, political, moral, religious, benevolent, protective, or mutual purposes; to promote some public, scientific, or educational objective; or to facilitate business and not for purposes of trade or direct pecuniary profit.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>The rights and liabilities of an organization vary according to its form and substantive nature and do not depend on the title or name applied to it. Unincorporated associations include diverse types of organizations serving widely disparate purposes and goals. They may be not-for-profit organizations or business associations organized for profit, such as partnerships or joint ventures.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>For forms relating to business partnerships, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="18:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;18:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>For forms relating to joint ventures, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="19:1 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;19:1 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nature of associations and clubs, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1 et seq." secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;1 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nature and kinds of associations and clubs, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1, 2" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;1, 2</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> A voluntary, unincorporated membership association as such is neither a partnership nor a corporation.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text><cite type="case">Martin v. Curran, 303 N.Y. 276, 101 N.E.2d 683 (1951)</cite>; <cite type="case">Heifetz v. Rockaway Point Volunteer Fire Dept., 124 N.Y.S.2d 257 (Sup 1953), order aff&apos;d, 282 A.D. 1062, 126 N.Y.S.2d 604 (2d Dep&apos;t 1953)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Characteristics of associations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="3">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;3</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Associations, compared to, and distinguished from, partnerships and corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;1</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> However, for the express purpose of the provision of the General Association Law permitting actions against associations, any partnership or other company of persons having a president or treasurer is deemed to be an association.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-genassns" secref="13">Gen. Ass&apos;ns Law &sect;13</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>Unincorporated associations are not regarded as legal entities because they are not artificial persons and have no existence separate and apart from their members.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text><cite type="case">Chinuch v. Congregation Lubavitch, Inc., 82 Misc. 3d 29, 204 N.Y.S.3d 380 (App. Term 2024)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text><cite type="case">Barrett v. New York Republican State Committee, 213 A.D.2d 989, 625 N.Y.S.2d 769 (4th Dep&apos;t 1995)</cite>; <cite type="case">L &amp; L Associates Holding Corp. v. Charity United Baptist Church, 34 Misc. 3d 355, 935 N.Y.S.2d 450 (Dist. Ct. 2011)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> An association is generally formed by the voluntary action of a number of individuals in associating themselves together under a common name for the accomplishment of some lawful purpose. Its organization, like corporations, does not usually depend upon compliance with any statutory provisions, although such associations may be subject to legislative control.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Unincorporated associations, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;5</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Unincorporated associations, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;1</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|18|30:18"><para.text>The contract of association, the constitution, or the bylaws determine the purpose for which the association is formed. There is no restriction on the power of an unincorporated association to prescribe reasonable rules in order to accomplish its purposes, as long as such rules do not violate law or public policy.<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, and regulations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4 to 8" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;4 to 8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, and regulations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5, 6" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;5, 6</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:19</designator><name>Legal status of unincorporated association</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="101 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text>Although an unincorporated association is not a legal entity,<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text><cite type="case">Martin v. Curran, 303 N.Y. 276, 101 N.E.2d 683 (1951)</cite>; <cite type="case">Gillette v. Allen, 269 A.D. 441, 56 N.Y.S.2d 307 (4th Dep&apos;t 1945)</cite>; <cite type="case">Saxer v. Democratic County Committee of Erie County, 161 Misc. 35, 291 N.Y.S. 18 (Sup 1936)</cite>; <cite type="case">Meinhart v. Contresta, 194 N.Y.S. 593 (Sup 1922)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text>Under the New York Uniform Commercial Code, a &ldquo;person&rdquo; includes an individual or an association and an &ldquo;organization&rdquo; means a person other than an individual. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-ucc" secref="1-201" subref="(b)" pararef="(25)">NYUCC &dblsect;1-201(b)(25)</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-ucc" secref="1-201" subref="(b)" pararef="(27)">1-201(b)(27)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text>An instrument is payable to order when made payable to an unincorporated association, in which case it is payable to the association and may be indorsed or transferred by any person authorized to do so. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-ucc" secref="3-110" subref="(1)" pararef="(g)">NYUCC &sect;3-110(1)(g)</cite>. An order otherwise unconditional is not made conditional by the fact that it is limited to payment out of the entire assets of an unincorporated association by or on behalf of which the instrument is issued. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-ucc" secref="3-105" subref="(1)" pararef="(h)">NYUCC &sect;3-105(1)(h)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Characteristics of associations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="3">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;3</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Associations, compared to, and distinguished from, partnerships and corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="1">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;1</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> an action or a special proceeding may be maintained by or against the president or treasurer of such an association.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-genassns" secref="12">Gen. Ass&apos;ns Law &dblsect;12</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-genassns" secref="13">13</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr5" titlename="Liability of hotel, motel, resort, or private membership club or association operating swimming pool, for injury or death of guest or member" volref="55" pageref="463">Liability of hotel, motel, resort, or private membership club or association operating swimming pool, for injury or death of guest or member, 55 A.L.R.5th 463</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Liability of member of unincorporated association for tortious acts of association&apos;s nonmember agent or employee" volref="62" pageref="1165">Liability of member of unincorporated association for tortious acts of association&apos;s nonmember agent or employee, 62 A.L.R.3d 1165</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Liability of social club for injury to or death of nonmember" volref="15" pageref="1013">Liability of social club for injury to or death of nonmember, 15 A.L.R.3d 1013</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Rights and liabilities arising out of contract for lifetime membership in social or fraternal club or association" volref="10" pageref="1357">Rights and liabilities arising out of contract for lifetime membership in social or fraternal club or association, 10 A.L.R.3d 1357</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alrfed1" titlename="Association of persons as proper representative of class under Rule 23 of Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing maintenance of class actions" volref="63" pageref="361">Association of persons as proper representative of class under Rule 23 of Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing maintenance of class actions, 63 A.L.R. Fed. 361</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alrfed1" titlename="Determination of citizenship of unincorporated associations, for federal diversity of citizenship purposes, in actions by or against such associations" volref="14" pageref="849">Determination of citizenship of unincorporated associations, for federal diversity of citizenship purposes, in actions by or against such associations, 14 A.L.R. Fed. 849</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Liability of association, generally, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="14, 31 to 37" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;14, 31 to 37</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Liability of association and members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="27 to 30" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;27 to 30</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> However, in the absence of a statutory authorization, an unincorporated organization or association cannot purchase or hold either real or personal property in its own right or accept such property by devise or bequest.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Capacity of unincorporated association to take or hold property, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="9">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;9</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Power to acquire and hold property, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Property ostensibly held by an unincorporated association is deemed to belong jointly to the members.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text><cite type="case">McMahon v. Rauhr, 47 N.Y. 67, 1871 WL 9874 (1871)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Interest of members in property, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="20">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;20</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Rights of members in organization&apos;s property and assets, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text>An unincorporated association or club is entitled to protection against the use of its name by another organization, and may resort to injunctive relief to restrain the use of its name by others, unless precluded by equitable defenses.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|19|30:19"><para.text><cite type="case">Democratic Organization of County of Richmond v. Democratic Organization of County of Richmond, 253 A.D. 820, 1 N.Y.S.2d 349 (2d Dep&apos;t 1938)</cite>; <cite type="case">Rudolph v. Southern Beneficial League, 7 N.Y.S. 135 (Sup 1889)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another" volref="37" pageref="277">Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another, 37 A.L.R.3d 277</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Right to exclusive use of name, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="12">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;12</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>2</designator><name>Form Drafting Principles</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:20</designator><name>Articles and bylaws</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="111 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;111 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>An unincorporated association may promote its aims and purposes and advance the best interests of its members in any legitimate way.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text><cite type="case">Burt v. Oneida Community, 137 N.Y. 346, 33 N.E. 307 (1893)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> To that end, it may adopt a constitution, also called a &ldquo;charter&rdquo; or &ldquo;articles of association,&rdquo; and bylaws for the regulation of its internal government, its policy, and the management of its affairs. The articles of association, bylaws, and the rules and regulations of the association constitute a contract between the organization and its members and govern members&apos; relations among themselves and with the organization.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4 to 8" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;4 to 8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5, 6" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;5, 6</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>There is no restriction upon the power of an unincorporated association to prescribe reasonable rules, except that they must be adopted in conformity with the agreement of the members and must not be contrary to the law. An association regulation that is repugnant to the laws of the state may be declared to be void and of no effect by the courts. Moreover, to be valid and binding, the bylaws of any organization must be reasonable, and if a regulation of an association is clearly unreasonable, the courts will disregard it. Furthermore, a majority of the members cannot by vote deprive other members of their rights under the organization&apos;s constitution.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4 to 8" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;4 to 8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5, 6" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;5, 6</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>Articles of an association will be read in light of the rule that limits the general words of an instrument to its specific object, and ambiguity may be explained by prior custom of the organization and interpretations by the organization itself through its officers and authorized tribunals.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4 to 8" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;4 to 8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5, 6" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;5, 6</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>Although an unincorporated association is not required to have either a constitution or bylaws, such documents should be drawn up as they constitute the association&apos;s fundamental law.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>Unlike incorporated associations or clubs, no particular provisions are required to be included in the articles of an unincorporated organization. An organization may divide its organic law as it desires among a constitution, bylaws, and a set of rules and regulations. It is recommended that the basic laws and rules be drafted contemporaneously to preclude both the inadvertent omission of desired provisions and the inclusion of inconsistent ones.</para.text></para>
<feature.para.block><name.block><name>Practice Tip:</name></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>While there is no requirement that articles of association and bylaws be in writing, to avoid dissension and to ensure continuity, these documents should be prepared in writing.</para.text></para>
</feature.para.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>Many of the forms of the certificate of incorporation and bylaws and individual provisions for such forms appearing in the division of this chapter dealing with incorporated associations<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>See <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:68 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;30:68 et seq.</cite></para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> may, with some modification, be utilized by an unincorporated association or club.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|20|30:20"><para.text>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purpose for which it was organized whenever the welfare of the association so requires. Where the constitution and bylaws of an unincorporated association provide for amendment, the constitution and bylaws may be amended in the mode prescribed.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Amendment or repeal of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Amendment or repeal of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:21</designator><name>Articles and bylaws<sep/>Important matters to be covered</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="101 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Important matters to be treated in either the articles or the bylaws, or both, include:<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>For checklists of matters to consider when drafting governing instruments for an association, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:22">&sect;30:22</cite> (articles of association or constitution), and <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:23">&sect;30:23</cite> (bylaws).</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>1</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Purposes and powers of the association. An unincorporated association may be designed to serve any legitimate purpose<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text><cite type="case">Wicks v. Monihan, 130 N.Y. 232, 29 N.E. 139 (1891)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> and may promote its aims and purposes and advance the best interests of its members in any legitimate way.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text><cite type="case">Burt v. Oneida Community, 137 N.Y. 346, 33 N.E. 307 (1893)</cite>; <cite type="case">Robinson v. Dahm, 94 Misc. 729, 159 N.Y.S. 1053 (Sup 1916)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4 to 8" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;4 to 8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5, 6" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;5, 6</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>2</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Authorities and duties of officers and other bodies, such as a governing council.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>3</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Qualifications of and admission to membership. A voluntary association may prescribe the necessary qualifications for membership in the association and may limit its membership by tests of learning or skill. Membership in a voluntary association is a privilege that may be given or withheld at the association&apos;s pleasure.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>The courts cannot compel the admission of any individual to an unincorporated association. <cite type="case">McKane v. Democratic General Committee, 123 N.Y. 609, 25 N.E. 1057 (1890)</cite>, holding that no rights of property, of person, or of citizenship are affected or infringed upon by the refusal of admission.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Membership and rights of members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="15 to 20" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;15 to 20</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Membership and rights of members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="13 et seq." secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;13 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>4</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Classification of members and rights, privileges and liabilities of each membership class. All members in good standing have a legally enforceable right to attend the meetings of the association and to participate in its deliberations and decisions.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text><cite type="case">In re Bandanza, 132 Misc. 817, 230 N.Y.S. 460 (Sup 1928)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Meetings of members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Meetings of members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;17</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Where the laws of the association prescribe the time and manner of giving notice, notice to members must be given as so prescribed.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text><cite type="case">In re Bandanza, 132 Misc. 817, 230 N.Y.S. 460 (Sup 1928)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Notice of meetings of members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Notice of meetings of members, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;17</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>5</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Suspension or expulsion of members. An association may suspend, expel, or terminate the membership of any member in accordance with the provisions of its governing instruments as long as such provisions are reasonable.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Ordinarily, the rules and bylaws of a voluntary, unincorporated association provide for the course of procedure to be followed in disciplining or expelling members, and such disciplinary action, in order to be valid, must be made in the regular manner in conformity with such rules and bylaws. <cite type="case">Harmon v. Matthews, 27 N.Y.S.2d 656 (Sup 1941)</cite>; <cite type="case">Stein v. Marks, 44 Misc. 140, 89 N.Y.S. 921 (Sup 1904)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="21 to 24" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;21 to 24</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="22 to 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;22 to 26</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> However, before taking such action, the association must afford the member reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard.<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text><cite type="case">Rodier v. Huddell, 232 A.D. 531, 250 N.Y.S. 336 (1st Dep&apos;t 1931)</cite>; <cite type="case">Williamson v. Randolph, 48 Misc. 96, 96 N.Y.S. 644 (Sup 1905)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Disciplinary proceedings, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="22">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;22</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Necessity and sufficiency of notice and hearing, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="24">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;24</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> If proceedings in a disciplinary hearing are had fairly, in good faith, and pursuant to the laws of the organization and if there was nothing in the proceedings in violation of the law of the land, the decision of the organization&apos;s tribunal to suspend or expel a member is conclusive.<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text><cite type="case">Wilcox v. Supreme Council of Royal Arcanum, 210 N.Y. 370, 104 N.E. 624 (1914)</cite>; <cite type="case">Spiegelman v. Engineers Country Club, Inc., 38 A.D.2d 728, 329 N.Y.S.2d 166 (2d Dep&apos;t 1972)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="21 to 24" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;21 to 24</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Discipline of members; expulsion or suspension, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="22 to 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;22 to 26</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<feature.para.block><name.block><name>Practice Tip:</name></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>It is recommended that a specific procedure for notice and hearing be set forth in the bylaws, although the governing instruments may provide for such procedure by implication.</para.text></para>
</feature.para.block></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>6</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Procedure for enforcement of sanctions.<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Judicial review of expulsion or suspension, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="23">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;23</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Judicial review of expulsion or suspension, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="25, 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;25, 26</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>7</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Liability of members to third persons.<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Liability of members for acts and debts of association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="19">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;19</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Liability of members for acts and debts of association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="27 to 30" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;27 to 30</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>8</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Amendment of articles and bylaws. The bylaws or articles of association should provide that amendments are valid and binding on all members, including those who may have voted against them. The bylaws of an unincorporated association are deemed to be a contract between the members determining their rights, powers, duties, and liabilities. As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purpose for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. Where the constitution and bylaws of an unincorporated association provide for amendment, the constitution and bylaws may be amended in the mode prescribed.<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Amendment of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Amendment of constitution, bylaws, rules, and regulations, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>9</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Manner of dissolution and disposition of property of the association on dissolution.<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|21|30:21"><para.text>Generally, where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among the several contributors in proportion to the amount contributed or paid by them respectively. <cite type="case">Lafond v. Deems, 81 N.Y. 507, 1880 WL 12514 (1880)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Dissolution of unincorporated association, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Rights of members in organization&apos;s property and assets, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="20">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;20</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Rights of members in organization&apos;s property and assets, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Dissolution and liquidation, see <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="30">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;30</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>
</analytical.level.body>
</analytical.level>
<analytical.level>
<front>
<outline.name.block>
<designator>3</designator><name>Checklists</name></outline.name.block>
</front>
<analytical.level.body>
<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:22</designator><name>Checklist<sep/>Matters to be considered when drafting constitution or articles of association for an unincorporated association</name></outline.name.block>
<online.view>
<online.view.item>COL</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>NFP</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>CHK</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FCV</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FTR</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>EBL</online.view.item>
</online.view>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<check.list>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>1</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Name of association.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>2</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Location and complete address of association&apos;s offices.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>3</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Purposes for which association is formed.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Specific or primary purpose.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Other general purposes.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>4</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Statement that association is to be not-for-profit.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>5</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Powers of association.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>6</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Form of government.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Titles and numbers of members of governing body.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Names and addresses of the first members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Meeting of governing body.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Quorum requirements for conducting business.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Appointment and duties of committees.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>f</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Titles, number, and duties of officers.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>7</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Membership.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Classification of members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Rights, privileges, and liabilities of each class of members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Qualifications of members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Admission to membership.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Suspension or expulsion of members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>f</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Termination of membership.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>g</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Notice and hearing of charges against member.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>8</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Meeting of association.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Regular meetings.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Special meeting.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Time and place of meeting.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Manner of giving notice.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Quorum requirements.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>9</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Authorization to adopt bylaws.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>10</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Manner of amending bylaws.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>11</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Manner of amending articles or constitution.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>12</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Amendments to articles and bylaws to be binding on all members, including those who may have voted against such amendments.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>13</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Manner of dissolution.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>14</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Distribution of assets on dissolution.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list>
<note.block>
<item.reference.block>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>1.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>An unincorporated association is entitled to protection against the use of its name by another organization and may resort to injunctive relief to restrain the use of its name by others. <cite type="case">Democratic Organization of County of Richmond v. Democratic Organization of County of Richmond, 253 A.D. 820, 1 N.Y.S.2d 349 (2d Dep&apos;t 1938)</cite>; <cite type="case">Rudolph v. Southern Beneficial League, 7 N.Y.S. 135 (Sup 1889)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="120 to 123" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;120 to 123</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another" volref="37" pageref="277">Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another, 37 A.L.R.3d 277</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="12">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;12</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>3.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Societies and clubs may perform all necessary governmental acts in any way consonant with their purposes and with the laws, internal and external, to which they are subject. <cite type="case">Wicks v. Monihan, 130 N.Y. 232, 29 N.E. 139 (1891)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Purpose clauses, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:74 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;30:74 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>4.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Qualifying for tax-exempt status, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:2 to 30:9" secrange="y">&dblsect;30:2 to 30:9</cite>.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>5.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Voluntary, unincorporated associations have inherent power, somewhat akin to the police power of a state, and are under a duty to provide for the welfare of their members and to regulate their affairs so as to attain the objects and purposes for which they were constituted. <cite type="case">Weinstock v. Ladisky, 197 Misc. 859, 98 N.Y.S.2d 85 (Sup 1950)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="162">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;162</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="9">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;9</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="9 to 12" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;9 to 12</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>6.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>An association is generally formed by the voluntary action of a number of individuals in associating themselves together under a common name for the accomplishment of some lawful purpose; its organization, as in the case of corporations, does not usually depend upon compliance with any statutory provisions. <cite type="case">Weidenfeld v. Keppler, 84 A.D. 235, 82 N.Y.S. 634 (1st Dep&apos;t 1903), aff&apos;d, 176 N.Y. 562, 68 N.E. 1125 (1903)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;5</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;4</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>7.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>A voluntary association has a right to restrict its membership to those willing to sign the uniform agreement which constitutes its contractual relationship with its members. <cite type="case">Importers&apos; &amp; Exporters&apos; Ins. Co. v. Rhoades, 209 A.D. 689, 205 N.Y.S. 628 (1st Dep&apos;t 1924), rev&apos;d on other grounds, 239 N.Y. 420, 146 N.E. 648 (1925)</cite>. In general, whether to grant or refuse membership in a voluntary association is a matter under the complete control of the organization itself, and its ruling in this respect is not subject to review by the courts. <cite type="case">Simons v. Berry, 210 A.D. 90, 205 N.Y.S. 442 (1st Dep&apos;t 1924)</cite>; <cite type="case">Barazani v. Brighton and Manhattan Beach Chamber of Commerce and Civic Ass&apos;n, Inc., 20 Misc. 2d 844, 194 N.Y.S.2d 426 (Sup 1959)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>However, an association&apos;s authority to restrict membership is not unlimited where restriction is based on race, gender, or ethnicity. Thus, refusal of membership on such grounds can be challenged under circumstances, using antidiscrimination laws applicable to public entities. Associations, like corporations and other legislatively defined entities, are within the sphere of legislative control. <cite type="case">New York State Club Ass&apos;n, Inc. v. City of New York, 487 U.S. 1, 108 S. Ct. 2225, 101 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1988)</cite> (upholding New York City law forbidding discrimination in certain clubs with greater than 400 members in the interest of assuring equal access to business opportunities to women and minorities).</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="141 to 160" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;141 to 160</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="15 to 24" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;15 to 24</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="13 to 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;13 to 26</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>8.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>All members in good standing of an association have a legally enforceable right to attend the meetings of the society and participate in its deliberations and decisions. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="171">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;171</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;17</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>8c.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Notice of a meeting of a voluntary association must include the time, place, and object of the meeting. <cite type="case">Goller v. Stubenhaus, 77 Misc. 29, 134 N.Y.S. 1043 (Sup 1912)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;17</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>8d.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Where the laws for the internal government of the association ordain the time or manner of giving notice, notice to members must be given as so prescribed. <cite type="case">In re Bandanza, 132 Misc. 817, 230 N.Y.S. 460 (Sup 1928)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="171">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;171</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;17</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>10.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purposes for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="128">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;128</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>11.</designator></name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="128">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;128</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>12.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Where the association has the right to alter its constitution and bylaws, a member is deemed to have consented to and acquiesced in amendments duly made. <cite type="case">Havens v. King, 221 A.D. 475, 224 N.Y.S. 193 (3d Dep&apos;t 1927), aff&apos;d, 250 N.Y. 617, 166 N.E. 346 (1929)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="128">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;128</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>13.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>Where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among its several members or contributors. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="341 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;341 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="38">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;38</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>14.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>The dissolution of an association as a body entitles the members thereof at the time of the dissolution to a distribution, in accordance with their just interests, of its funds and other property. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|22|30:22"><para.text>In the absence of an applicable statutory plan, the assets of a dissolved association should be distributed in accordance with the rules of the organization. <cite type="case">In re American Dramatic Fund Ass&apos;n, 3 N.Y.S. 793 (Sup 1889)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="345">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;345</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
</item.reference.block>
</note.block>
</check.list>
</section.body>

<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>1</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Location and address of organization headquarters or office.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>2</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Form and structure of government.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Designation of governing body.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Composition of governing body; qualifications, manner of election, and term of service of members of governing body.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Powers, duties, and liabilities of members of governing body.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Limitations on authority and powers of governing bodies and officers.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Composition and duties of committees.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>f</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Titles, number, and duties of officers.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>3</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Meetings of governing body.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Manner of giving notice of meetings.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Time and place of meetings.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Requirements of quorum.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>4</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Membership structure.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Qualifications for membership.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Classes of membership and rights and obligations of each class.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Regulations concerning the admission of members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Property, voting, and other rights of members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Entrance or initiation fees for new members.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>f</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Amount and due date of monthly, semi-annual, or annual (or as the case may be) dues.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>5</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Regulation of membership.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">

<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Manner of withdrawal, suspension, and expulsion of members and manner of reinstatement.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Transfer of membership.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Termination of membership.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>f</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Notice and hearing of charges against member.</para.text></para></list.item>
</list></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>6</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Meetings of members.</para.text></para>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Dates for regular meetings and procedure for calling special meetings.</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Number of members necessary to constitute quorum.</para.text></para></list.item>

</list></list.item>

<list.item><name.block><designator>8</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Liability of members and association to third persons.</para.text></para></list.item>
