</list>
<note.block>
<item.reference.block>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>2.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>An association is generally formed by the voluntary action of a number of individuals in associating themselves together under a common name for the accomplishment of some lawful purpose; its organization, as in the case of corporations, does not usually depend upon compliance with any statutory provisions. <cite type="case">Weidenfeld v. Keppler, 84 A.D. 235, 82 N.Y.S. 634 (1st Dep&apos;t 1903), aff&apos;d, 176 N.Y. 562, 68 N.E. 1125 (1903)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="101 et seq." numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;101 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;5</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="4">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;4</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>2b.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>The bylaws govern the procedure and implementation of elections of officers or directors of the association.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="221 to 225" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;221 to 225</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>2c.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>The general rule of the law of agency holds one who assumes to act as agent for a principal who has no such legal status or existence individually liable on the contract made on behalf of his or her professed principal. However, in the absence of a personal promise or covenant, one signing a contract, who therein represents himself or herself to be the agent of an association as a disclosed and known principal, or who assumes to contract for such principal only, cannot be held personally liable upon the covenants contained in such contract. <cite type="case">Whitford v. Laidler, 94 N.Y. 145, 1883 WL 12735 (1883)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="201 to 203" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;201 to 203</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="14">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;14</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="27 to 30" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;27 to 30</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>4.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>A voluntary association has a right to restrict its membership to those willing to sign the uniform agreement which constitutes its contractual relationship with its members. <cite type="case">Importers&apos; &amp; Exporters&apos; Ins. Co. v. Rhoades, 209 A.D. 689, 205 N.Y.S. 628 (1st Dep&apos;t 1924), rev&apos;d on other grounds, 239 N.Y. 420, 146 N.E. 648 (1925)</cite>. In general, whether to grant or refuse membership in a voluntary association is a matter under the complete control of the organization itself, and its ruling in this respect is not subject to review by the courts. <cite type="case">Simons v. Berry, 210 A.D. 90, 205 N.Y.S. 442 (1st Dep&apos;t 1924)</cite>; <cite type="case">Barazani v. Brighton and Manhattan Beach Chamber of Commerce and Civic Ass&apos;n, Inc., 20 Misc. 2d 844, 194 N.Y.S.2d 426 (Sup 1959)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>However, an association&apos;s authority to restrict membership is not unlimited where restriction is based on race, gender, or ethnicity. Thus, refusal of membership on such grounds can be challenged under circumstances using antidiscrimination laws applicable to public entities. Associations, like corporations and other legislatively defined entities, are within the sphere of legislative control. <cite type="case">New York State Club Ass&apos;n, Inc. v. City of New York, 487 U.S. 1, 108 S. Ct. 2225, 101 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1988)</cite> (upholding New York City law forbidding discrimination in certain clubs with greater than 400 members in the interest of assuring equal access to business opportunities to women and minorities).</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="141 to 160" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;141 to 160</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="15 to 24" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;15 to 24</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="13 to 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;13 to 26</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>4f.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Provisions of the articles of association imposing upon members the payment of dues and assessments at stated times and subscribed to by them create a legal obligation upon the part of each member to pay such dues and assessments as long as the society remains a going concern and his or her membership therein continues. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;17</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="173">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;173</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;17</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="23">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;23</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>5a.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>An association may expel a member for a violation of its established rules for which expulsion is provided. <cite type="case">Marandino v. Westchester Country Club, Inc., 33 A.D.3d 800, 822 N.Y.S.2d 762 (2d Dep&apos;t 2006)</cite>; <cite type="case">Kelly v. Northport Yacht Club, Inc., 44 A.D.3d 858, 844 N.Y.S.2d 358 (2d Dep&apos;t 2007)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Within contracts of association there inheres a term binding members to loyal support of the society in the attainment of its proper purposes and that, for a gross breach of this obligation, the power of expulsion is impliedly conferred on the association. <cite type="case">Berich v. Ithaca Police Benev. Ass&apos;n, Inc., 23 A.D.3d 904, 804 N.Y.S.2d 833 (3d Dep&apos;t 2005)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="150 to 152" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;150 to 152</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="244">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;244</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="21">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;21</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="23">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;23</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>5c.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Where the constitution and bylaws of a voluntary association reasonably set forth grounds for expulsion and provide for a hearing upon notice to the member, judicial review of such proceedings is unavailable, unless the reason for expulsion is not a violation of the constitution or bylaws or is so trivial as to suggest that the action of the association was capricious or corrupt or unless the association failed to administer its own rules fairly. <cite type="case">Marandino v. Westchester Country Club, Inc., 33 A.D.3d 800, 822 N.Y.S.2d 762 (2d Dep&apos;t 2006)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="150 to 152" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;150 to 152</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="244">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;244</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="21">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;21</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="22 to 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;22 to 26</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>5d.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>The right of membership in a voluntary unincorporated association is a privilege that may not be transferred or sold without the consent of the association. <cite type="case">Branagan v. Buckman, 67 Misc. 242, 122 N.Y.S. 610 (Sup 1910), aff&apos;d, 145 A.D. 950, 130 N.Y.S. 1106 (3d Dep&apos;t 1911)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="156">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;156</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="16">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;16</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="20">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;20</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>5f.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Ordinarily, the rules and bylaws of a voluntary unincorporated association provide for the course of procedure to be followed in disciplining or expelling members, and such disciplinary action, in order to be valid, must be made in the regular manner in conformity with such rules and bylaws. <cite type="case">Harmon v. Matthews, 27 N.Y.S.2d 656 (Sup 1941)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Club member&apos;s right to be advised of charges against him or her to receive notice of disciplinary hearing and to be given opportunity to appear and be heard at hearing are fundamental rights that must be afforded even in absence of club bylaws. <cite type="case">Anderson v. Board of Directors of Powelton Club, 183 Misc. 2d 200, 702 N.Y.S.2d 762 (Sup 1999)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="150 to 152" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;150 to 152</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="244">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;244</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="22">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;22</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="24">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;24</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>6.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>All members in good standing of an association have a legally enforceable right to attend the meetings of the society and participate in its deliberations and decisions. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="171">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;171</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;18</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="17">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;17</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>7.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purposes for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="128">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;128</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>8.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Homeowners&apos; association did not have duty to warn or protect motorist who was driving on street owned by association from dangerous condition created by tree that was located on neighboring property and thus was not liable for injuries allegedly sustained by motorist as result of tree falling on vehicle. <cite type="case">Crawford v. Forest Hills Gardens, 16 A.D.3d 535, 792 N.Y.S.2d 135 (2d Dep&apos;t 2005)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="211 to 214" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;211 to 214</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="201 to 203" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;201 to 203</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="12 to 14" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;12 to 14</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="27 to 30" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;27 to 30</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>9.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>Where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among its several members or contributors. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>The dissolution of an association as a body entitles the members thereof at the time of the dissolution to a distribution, in accordance with their just interests, of its funds and other property. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>In the absence of an applicable statutory plan, the assets of a dissolved association should be distributed in accordance with the rules of the organization. <cite type="case">In re American Dramatic Fund Ass&apos;n, 3 N.Y.S. 793 (Sup 1889)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="341 to 347" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;341 to 347</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11, 20" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;11, 20</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18, 38" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;18, 38</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Item</label><designator>10.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|23|30:23"><para.text>A society, club, or association does have the right to protection against the copying of its insignia, badges, and emblems by another organization. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="12">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;12</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="120 to 123" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;120 to 123</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="12">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;12</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
</item.reference.block>
</note.block>

<section.block>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:24</designator><name>Articles of association</name></outline.name.block>
<online.view>
<online.view.item>FMS</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>NFP</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>COL</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FCV</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FTR</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>EBL</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>TEM</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>MTD</online.view.item>
</online.view>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<form uuid="Id53700901b6411e684899cfd92da4eb0">
<form.name.block><name>ARTICLES OF ASSOCIATION</name></form.name.block>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>To further common purposes, the members agree to organize under these articles of association.</form.text></form.para>
<form.unit>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>1</designator><name>NAME</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The name of this association shall be <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of association&rsqb;</inline.instr>.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>2</designator><name>PRINCIPAL OFFICE</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The principal office of the association shall be at <inline.instr>&lsqb;office address of association&rsqb;</inline.instr>, <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of city&rsqb;</inline.instr>, <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of county&rsqb;</inline.instr>, State of New York. <inline.instr>&lsqb;OPTIONAL: The association may have such other offices as may, from time to time, be designated by its members or its executive committee.&rsqb;</inline.instr></form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>3</designator><name>PURPOSES</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The purposes for which this association is formed are:</form.text></form.para>
<form.unit>
<form.item><name.block><designator>A</designator></name.block><form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>To own, operate, and maintain an association exclusively for the pleasure, entertainment, and recreation of its members.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><name.block><designator>B</designator></name.block><form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>To do anything necessary and proper for the accomplishment of any purposes set forth in the statement of principles adopted by the founders of this association.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><name.block><designator>C</designator></name.block><form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>This association is organized and operated exclusively for the above-stated purposes and for other not-for-profit purposes. No part of any net earnings shall inure to the benefit of any private member.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
</form.unit></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>4</designator><name>POWERS</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>In furtherance of the objectives described above, but not in limitation of such objectives, the association shall have the power, insofar as such power is conferred or is not limited, by law, to make and perform contracts for any lawful purpose; to engage in various funding and fund-raising activities; and to acquire, own, hold, operate, and maintain such property as to effectuate its purposes.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>5</designator><name>MEMBERSHIP</name></name.block></head>
<form.unit>
<form.item><name.block><designator>A</designator></name.block><form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The association shall have one class of members only. All voting rights and other rights, interests, and privileges of each member shall be equal.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><name.block><designator>B</designator></name.block><form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The rights and privileges of members, their liability for dues and assessments, and the termination and transfer of membership shall be as stated in the bylaws.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
</form.unit></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>6</designator><name>GOVERNING BODY</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The powers of the association shall be exercised and its property controlled by a council comprised of <inline.instr>&lsqb;number of members&rsqb;</inline.instr> members. The qualifications, the time and manner of election, the terms and duties of office, and the manner of filling vacancies shall be set forth in the bylaws.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>7</designator><name>OFFICERS</name></name.block></head>
<form.unit>
<form.item><name.block><designator>A</designator></name.block><form.para><form.text>Elective officers.</form.text></form.para>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>The officers of this association shall be a President, Vice President, secretary, and treasurer. Other offices and officers may be established or appointed by members of the association at the regular annual meeting. The qualifications of, the time and manner of electing, the duties of, the terms of office of, and the manner of removing officers shall be set forth in the bylaws.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><name.block><designator>B</designator></name.block><form.para><form.text>Standing committees.</form.text></form.para>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>This association shall have at least two standing committees: The <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of council&rsqb;</inline.instr> shall elect annually, from among its members, an executive committee of <inline.instr>&lsqb;number of persons on executive committee&rsqb;</inline.instr> persons and a committee on admissions of <inline.instr>&lsqb;number of persons on admissions committee&rsqb;</inline.instr> persons. Other committees may be specified in the bylaws or may be appointed from time to time by the <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of council&rsqb;</inline.instr>.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
</form.unit></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>8</designator><name>AMENDMENTS TO ARTICLES</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>These articles may be amended or repealed, in whole or in part, only by majority vote of this association&apos;s members at an organized meeting of the association.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>9</designator><name>BYLAWS</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>Bylaws will be hereafter adopted. Such bylaws may be amended or repealed, in whole or in part, in the manner they provide, and the amendments to the bylaws shall be binding on all members, including those who may have voted against them.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>10</designator><name>DISSOLUTION</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>This association shall be dissolved and its affairs wound up <inline.instr>&lsqb;specification of manner of voluntary dissolution&rsqb;</inline.instr>.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
<form.item><head><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>11</designator><name>DISTRIBUTION OF PROPERTY ON DISSOLUTION</name></name.block></head>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>In the event of dissolution, property of the association shall be distributed as follows: <inline.instr>&lsqb;specification of method of distribution&rsqb;</inline.instr>.</form.text></form.para></form.item>
</form.unit>
<form.para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><form.text>These articles of association are adopted on <inline.instr>&lsqb;date of adoption&rsqb;</inline.instr>, at <inline.instr>&lsqb;address of adoption&rsqb;</inline.instr>, <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of city&rsqb;</inline.instr>, <inline.instr>&lsqb;name of county&rsqb;</inline.instr>, State of New York.</form.text></form.para>
<signature.block ref="manual">
<signature.group position="r">
<form.vertical.space amt="1"/>
<form.line align="l" lineover="y"><inline.instr>&lsqb;Names of members&rsqb;</inline.instr></form.line>
</signature.group>
</signature.block>
<note.block>
<note.group note.head="taxnotes">
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>A club organized for pleasure, recreation, and other nonprofitable purposes will not be exempt from taxation for any taxable year if, at any time during such taxable year, the charter, bylaws, or other governing instrument of the organization or any written policy statement of the organization contains a provision that provides for discrimination against any person on the basis of race, color, or religion. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(i)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>A not-for-profit association may or may not be tax exempt, depending on its purposes and powers. See <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:2 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;30:2 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>See <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:20 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;30:20 et seq.</cite> as to function and content of articles.</para.text></para>
</note.group>
<item.reference.block>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>1.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>An unincorporated association is entitled to protection against the use of its name by another organization and may resort to injunctive relief to restrain the use of its name by others. <cite type="case">Democratic Organization of County of Richmond v. Democratic Organization of County of Richmond, 253 A.D. 820, 1 N.Y.S.2d 349 (2d Dep&apos;t 1938)</cite>; <cite type="case">Rudolph v. Southern Beneficial League, 7 N.Y.S. 135 (Sup 1889)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Associations" numref="120 to 123" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Associations &key;120 to 123</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another" volref="37" pageref="277">Right of charitable or religious association or corporation to protection against use of same or similar name by another, 37 A.L.R.3d 277</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="12">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;12</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>3.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>Societies and clubs may perform all necessary governmental acts in any way consonant with their purposes and with the laws, internal and external, to which they are subject. <cite type="case">Wicks v. Monihan, 130 N.Y. 232, 29 N.E. 139 (1891)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>Purpose clauses, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:74 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;30:74 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>4.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>Voluntary, unincorporated associations have inherent power, somewhat akin to the police power of a state, and are under a duty to provide for the welfare of their members and to regulate their affairs so as to attain the objects and purposes for which they were constituted. <cite type="case">Weinstock v. Ladisky, 197 Misc. 859, 98 N.Y.S.2d 85 (Sup 1950)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="9">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;9</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="9 to 12" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;9 to 12</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>5.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>A voluntary association has a right to restrict its membership to those willing to sign the uniform agreement which constitutes its contractual relationship with its members. <cite type="case">Importers&apos; &amp; Exporters&apos; Ins. Co. v. Rhoades, 209 A.D. 689, 205 N.Y.S. 628 (1st Dep&apos;t 1924), rev&apos;d on other grounds, 239 N.Y. 420, 146 N.E. 648 (1925)</cite>. In general, whether to grant or refuse membership in a voluntary association is a matter under the complete control of the organization itself, and its ruling in this respect is not subject to review by the courts. <cite type="case">Simons v. Berry, 210 A.D. 90, 205 N.Y.S. 442 (1st Dep&apos;t 1924)</cite>; <cite type="case">Barazani v. Brighton and Manhattan Beach Chamber of Commerce and Civic Ass&apos;n, Inc., 20 Misc. 2d 844, 194 N.Y.S.2d 426 (Sup 1959)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>However, an association&apos;s authority to restrict membership is not unlimited where restriction is based on race, gender, or ethnicity. Thus, refusal of membership on such grounds can be challenged under circumstances, using antidiscrimination laws applicable to public entities. Associations, like corporations and other legislatively defined entities, are within the sphere of legislative control. <cite type="case">New York State Club Ass&apos;n, Inc. v. City of New York, 487 U.S. 1, 108 S. Ct. 2225, 101 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1988)</cite> (upholding New York City law forbidding discrimination in certain clubs with greater than 400 members in the interest of assuring equal access to business opportunities to women and minorities).</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>The right of membership in a voluntary unincorporated association is a privilege that may not be transferred or sold without the consent of the association. <cite type="case">Branagan v. Buckman, 67 Misc. 242, 122 N.Y.S. 610 (Sup 1910), aff&apos;d, 145 A.D. 950, 130 N.Y.S. 1106 (3d Dep&apos;t 1911)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="15 to 24" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;15 to 24</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="13 to 26" secrange="y">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;13 to 26</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>7.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>The bylaws govern the procedure and implementation of elections of officers or directors of the association. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>8.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>As a general rule, unless forbidden by the organic law, an association, club, or society may alter, amend, or repeal its laws or enact others consistent with the purposes for which it was organized, whenever the welfare of the association so requires. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="7">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;7</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="8">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;8</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>9.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>The contract between a new member and the association includes the constitution and bylaws of that association to which the new member is deemed to have consented. Furthermore, the bylaws and articles of association constitute a contract among the members of that association which the courts will enforce.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="6">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;6</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="5">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;5</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>10.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>Where the operations of a voluntary association have been discontinued, its objects and purposes being abandoned by common consent, a court of equity has jurisdiction to decree a dissolution and to distribute its funds among its several members or contributors. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="38">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;38</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>11.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>The dissolution of an association as a body entitles the members thereof at the time of the dissolution to a distribution, in accordance with their just interests, of its funds and other property. <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|24|30:24"><para.text>In the absence of an applicable statutory plan, the assets of a dissolved association should be distributed in accordance with the rules of the organization. <cite type="case">In re American Dramatic Fund Ass&apos;n, 3 N.Y.S. 793 (Sup 1889)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="11">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &sect;11</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="aj2" topicname="Associations and Clubs" secref="18">Am. Jur. 2d, Associations and Clubs &dblsect;18</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
</item.reference.block>
</note.block>
</form>
</section.body>
</section>
