<reference.entry><ref.text>Certificate of amendment or change; requisites and filing, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="154, 155" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;154, 155</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate of change must set forth the corporation&apos;s name and if it has been changed the name under which it was formed, the date its certificate of incorporation was filed by the Department of State, each change effected thereby, and the manner in which the change was authorized.<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="803-A" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;803-A(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Contents of certificate of change, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="154">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;154</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> A certificate of change which changes only the post office address to which the Secretary of State shall mail a copy of any process against the corporation served upon him or her or the registered agent&apos;s address, provided the address being changed is the address of a person, partnership, or other corporation whose address, as agent, is the address to be changed or who has been designated as registered agent for such corporation, may be signed and delivered to the Department of State by such agent.<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="803-A" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;803-A(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Contents of certificate of change, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="154">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;154</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> In addition to the above requirements for the certificate of change, the certificate must include statements that notice of the proposed change was mailed to the corporation by the party signing the certificate not less than 30 days prior to the date of delivery to the Department and that the corporation has not objected thereto and that the party signing the certificate is the agent of the corporation to whose address the Secretary of State is required to mail copies of any process against the corporation served upon him or her or the registered agent, if such be the case.<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="803-A" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;803-A(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Contents of certificate of change, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="154">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;154</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Such a certificate signed and delivered will not be deemed to effect a change of location of the office of the corporation in whose behalf the certificate is filed.<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="803-A" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;803-A(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Contents of certificate of change, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="154">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;154</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text>A registered agent may resign as such agent by delivering to the Department of State a certificate, entitled &ldquo;Certificate of Resignation of Registered Agent of (Name of Designating Corporation) Under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="305">Section 305 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law</cite>.&rdquo;<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="305" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;305(c)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate must be signed by the registered agent and must contain the following provisions:</para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>(a)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text>that he or she resigns as registered agent for the designating corporation;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(b)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text>the date the certificate of incorporation or the application for authority of the designating corporation was filed by the Department of State; and</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(c)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text>that the agent has sent a copy of the certificate of resignation by registered mail to the designating corporation at the post office address on file in the Department of State specified for the mailing of process or, if such address is the address of the registered agent, then to the office of the designating corporation in the jurisdiction of its formation or incorporation.<footnote><footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="305" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;305(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text>The fee for filing a certificate of resignation, which is subject to change, is &dollar;30. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="104-A" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;104-A(c)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text>The designation of a registered agent will terminate 30 days after the filing by the Department of State of a certificate of resignation or a certificate containing a revocation or change of the designation, whichever is filed earlier.<footnote><footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="305" subref="(d)">N-PCL &sect;305(d)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> A certificate designating a new registered agent may be delivered to the Department of State by the corporation within such 30-day period or thereafter.<footnote><footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|51|30:47"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="305" subref="(d)">N-PCL &sect;305(d)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:48</designator><name>Corporate management</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Corporations and Business Organizations" numref="3420 to 3439" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3420 to 3439</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text>The activities of a not-for-profit corporation must be managed by a board of directors, except as otherwise provided in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or in the corporation&apos;s certificate of incorporation.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="701">N-PCL &sect;701</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> The directors must be at least 18 years of age, except in the case of certain specified youth groups.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="701">N-PCL &sect;701</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text>Unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation or bylaws, the board of directors has the authority to establish reasonable compensation of the corporation&apos;s members, directors, and officers for services rendered. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="515" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;515(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Specific requirements of the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="71">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;71</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Rights, duties, and liabilities of directors, officers, and agents, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="683 et seq." secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;683 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text>Although the certificate or bylaws may prescribe qualifications for directors,<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="701" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;701(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Qualifications of directors of not-for-profit corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="535">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;535</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> the number of directors must be at least three.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="702" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;702(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Number of directors for not-for-profit corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="537">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;537</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The bylaws or the certificate of incorporation may, however, provide for committees composed of directors.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="712" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;712(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Delegation of authority to executive and other committees, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="592 to 594" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;592 to 594</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text>Newly created directorships resulting from an increase in the number of directors elected or appointed at large and vacancies among such directors for any reason may be filled by vote of a majority of the directors then in office, regardless of their number, unless the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws provide that such newly created directorships or vacancies must be filled by vote of the members.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="705" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;705(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Construction and effect of corporate bylaws or articles relating to change in number of directors" volref="3" pageref="623">Construction and effect of corporate bylaws or articles relating to change in number of directors, 3 A.L.R.3d 623</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Filling board of director vacancies, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="550">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;550</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> A director elected or appointed, as the case may be, will hold office until the next annual meeting at which the election of directors is in the regular order of business and until a successor is elected or appointed and qualified.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|52|30:48"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="705" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;705(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Term of directors, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="546">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;546</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:49</designator><name>Whistleblower policy</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Corporations and Business Organizations" numref="3350 to 3499" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text>With certain exceptions, every corporation that has 20 or more employees and in the prior fiscal year had annual revenue in excess of &dollar;1 million must adopt, and oversee the implementation of, and compliance with, a whistleblower policy to protect from retaliation persons who report suspected improper conduct. Such policy must provide that no director, officer, key person, employee, or volunteer of a corporation who in good faith reports any action or suspected action taken by or within the corporation that is illegal, fraudulent or in violation of any adopted policy of the corporation will suffer intimidation, harassment, discrimination or other retaliation or, in the case of employees, adverse employment consequence.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715-b" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;715-b(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text><cite type="case">Rosen v. Zionist Organization of America, 225 A.D.3d 575, 206 N.Y.S.3d 595 (1st Dep&apos;t 2024)</cite> finding that a former employee, who had been terminated, sufficiently alleged a cause of action against the employer, president, and chair of the board under the statute that required certain nonprofit organizations to adopt and implement whistleblower policies to protect individuals who reported suspected improper conduct from retaliatory conduct; the former employee alleged he was an employee, rather than an officer, of the employer, and the employer did not refute such allegation. <cite type="case">Rosen v. Zionist Organization of America, 225 A.D.3d 575, 206 N.Y.S.3d 595 (1st Dep&apos;t 2024)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text><cite type="case">Ferris v. Lustgarten Foundation, 189 A.D.3d 1002, 138 N.Y.S.3d 517 (2d Dep&apos;t 2020)</cite> stating that the statute governing whistleblower policy of not-for-profit corporations created private right of action for employees who were retaliated against or subject to adverse employment consequences as a result of whistleblowing activities, where the statute was intended to protect employees who reported suspect actions of corporations in good faith, the legislative purpose was promoted by holding corporations accountable for retaliation against whistleblowers, and there was no regulatory agency to enforce a not-for-profit corporation&apos;s compliance with the statute.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text>The whistleblower policy must include the following provisions:</para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>(1)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text>Procedures for the reporting of violations or suspected violations of laws or corporate policies, including procedures for preserving the confidentiality of reported information;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(2)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text>A requirement that an employee, officer or director of the corporation be designated to administer the whistleblower policy and to report to the audit committee or other committee of independent directors or, if there are no such committees, to the board; and</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(3)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text>A requirement that a copy of the policy be distributed to all directors, officers, employees and to volunteers who provide substantial services to the corporation. Posting the policy on the corporation&apos;s website or at the corporation&apos;s offices in a conspicuous location accessible to employees and volunteers are among the methods a corporation may use to satisfy the distribution requirement.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|53|30:49"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715-b" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;715-b(b)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:50</designator><name>Conflict of interest policy</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Corporations and Business Organizations" numref="3350 to 3499" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3350 to 3499</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>With certain exceptions, the board must adopt, and oversee the implementation of, and compliance with, a conflict of interest policy to ensure that its directors, officers and key persons act in the corporation&apos;s best interest and comply with applicable legal requirements.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715-a" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;715-a(a)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>The conflict of interest policy must include, at a minimum, the following provisions:</para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>(1)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>a definition of the circumstances that constitute a conflict of interest;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(2)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>procedures for disclosing a conflict of interest or possible conflict of interest to the board or to a committee of the board, and procedures for the board or committee to determine whether a conflict exists;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(3)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>a requirement that the person with the conflict of interest not be present at or participate in board or committee deliberation or vote on the matter giving rise to such conflict, provided that nothing will prohibit the board or a committee from requesting that the person with the conflict of interest present information as background or answer questions at a committee or board meeting prior to the commencement of deliberations or voting relating thereto;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(4)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>a prohibition against any attempt by the person with the conflict to influence improperly the deliberation or voting on the matter giving rise to such conflict;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(5)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>a requirement that the existence and resolution of the conflict be documented in the corporation&apos;s records, including in the minutes of any meeting at which the conflict was discussed or voted upon; and</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(6)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>procedures for disclosing, addressing, and documenting related party transactions in accordance with <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715">N-PCL &sect;715</cite>.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715-a" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;715-a(b)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text>The conflict of interest policy must require that prior to the initial election of any director, and annually thereafter, such director must complete, sign and submit to the secretary of the corporation or a designated compliance officer a written statement identifying, to the best of the director&apos;s knowledge, any entity of which such director is an officer, director, trustee, member, owner (either as a sole proprietor or a partner), or employee and with which the corporation has a relationship, and any transaction in which the corporation is a participant and in which the director might have a conflicting interest. The policy must require that each director annually resubmit such written statement. The secretary of the corporation or the designated compliance officer must provide a copy of all completed statements to the chair of the audit committee or, if there is no audit committee, to the chair of the board.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|54|30:50"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715-a" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;715-a(c)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:51</designator><name>Membership</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Corporations and Business Organizations" numref="3400 to 3419" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3400 to 3419</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>A not-for-profit corporation may have one or more classes of members or, in the case of a charitable corporation, may have no members.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;601(a)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> Provision is usually made in the bylaws for classes of members, election of members, their voting rights, termination of membership, resignation, reinstatement, and transfer of membership.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>See <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:97 et seq." secrange="y">&dblsect;30:97 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Who may be members of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="823">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;823</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>The bylaws of a not-for-profit corporation may provide for the time, place, and manner of calling and conducting annual and special meetings of members<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="603">N-PCL &sect;603</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Calling of meetings of members, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="897">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Notice of meetings of members, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="901 to 907" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;901 to 907</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Time and place of meetings of members, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="908 to 910" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;908 to 910</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> and for the requirements of a quorum of members.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="608">N-PCL &sect;608</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Quorum requirements for not-for-profit corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="912">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;912</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Special meetings of the members may be called by the board or by such person or persons as may be authorized by the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws. In the absence of a provision in the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws for the convening of special meetings of the membership, such meetings may be convened by the members entitled to cast 10&percnt; of the total number of votes entitled to be cast at such meeting.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="603" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;603(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Calling of meetings of members, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="897">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>Fees, dues, and assessments may be imposed on and collected from the members of the corporation in accordance with the provisions of the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="507" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;507(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Fees, dues, and assessments, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="828, 829" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;828, 829</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Initiation fees, dues, or assessments may be levied on all classes of members or in different amounts or proportions for different classes of members, as the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws may provide but, in all cases, the fees, dues, and assessments payable by members of one class must be determined on the same basis.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="507" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;507(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Fees, dues, and assessments, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="828, 829" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;828, 829</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Additionally, the certificate of incorporation or, more commonly, the bylaws, may contain such provisions as are deemed necessary to enforce the collection of fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties, including provisions for the termination of membership, on reasonable notice, for nonpayment of such fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties and provisions for reinstatement of membership.<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="507" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;507(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Delinquencies and collection of fees, dues, and assessments, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="829">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;829</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law sets forth provisions regarding members and members&apos; rights, including meetings of members,<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="603 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;603 et seq.</cite></para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> voting rights,<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="611 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;611 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Right of members to vote, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="916">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;916</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> informal action by members entitled to vote,<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="614">N-PCL &sect;614</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Action by members without meeting, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="894">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;894</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> and voting agreements.<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="619">N-PCL &sect;619</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Validity of voting agreements, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="954">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;954</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>In accordance with the general rule regarding immunity of shareholders for the debts of a corporation, members are not personally liable for the debts, liabilities, or obligations of a not-for-profit corporation.<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="517" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;517(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonliability of members of not-for-profit corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="973">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;973</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>As noted above, the certificate of incorporation or, more commonly, the bylaws, may contain such provisions as are deemed necessary to enforce the collection of fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties, including provisions for the termination of membership, on reasonable notice, for nonpayment of such fees, dues, assessments, fines, or other penalties and provisions for reinstatement of membership.<footnote><footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="507" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;507(c)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> In the absence of a bylaw to the contrary, failure to pay dues does not automatically terminate membership.<footnote><footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Delinquencies and collection of dues, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="829">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;829</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Additionally, membership in a not-for-profit corporation is terminated by death, resignation, expulsion, expiration of a term of membership, or dissolution, judicial or nonjudicial, unless otherwise provided by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law, the certificate of incorporation, or the bylaws.<footnote><footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(e)">N-PCL &sect;601(e)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<feature.para.block><name.block><name>Practice Tip:</name></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>Inasmuch as property rights may be involved in connection with the expulsion of a member, the grounds and procedure (including fair trial, fair notice of the proceedings and charges or accusations, and an opportunity to be heard or to meet the accusations) provisions in the bylaws should be carefully drafted.<footnote><footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Discipline of members; suspension and expulsion, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="831 to 834" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;831 to 834</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</feature.para.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|55|30:51"><para.text>In the absence of a bylaw to the contrary, membership in a not-for-profit corporation terminates on tender or receipt of a resignation. In such case, formal acceptance by the corporation is not necessary to make the resignation effective. However, the bylaws may provide that no resignation shall be effective until accepted or until the member has discharged his or her indebtedness to the organization.<footnote><footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference><footnote.body>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Termination or forfeiture of membership; resignation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="835, 838" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;835, 838</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block><label>&sect;</label><designator>30:52</designator><name>Dissolution of corporation</name></outline.name.block>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Corporations and Business Organizations" numref="3480 to 3489" numrange="y">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3480 to 3489</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>A not-for-profit corporation has the power to cease its corporate activities and terminate its existence by voluntary dissolution.<footnote><footnote.reference>1</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1001 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;1001 et seq.</cite></para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> On dissolution, a not-for-profit corporation may make distributions to its members as permitted by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.reference>2</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="515" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;515(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Distribution of funds by nonprofit corporation absent dissolution" volref="51" pageref="1318">Distribution of funds by nonprofit corporation absent dissolution, 51 A.L.R.3d 1318</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporations, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The Law also provides for the dissolution of a not-for-profit corporation by an action for dissolution brought by the Attorney General based on one or more specified, statutory grounds.<footnote><footnote.reference>3</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1101 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;1101 et seq.</cite></para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> A foreign corporation authorized to conduct affairs in New York may surrender its authority by filing a certificate of surrender of authority with the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.reference>4</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The fee for filing a certificate of surrender of authority, which is subject to change, is &dollar;30. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="104-A" subref="(q)">N-PCL &sect;104-A(q)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1311">N-PCL &sect;1311</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate must set forth the foreign corporation&apos;s name as it appears on the index of names of existing and authorized foreign corporations of any type or kind in the Department of State and the fictitious name the corporation has agreed to use in this state pursuant to <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1301">Section 1301 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law</cite>.<footnote><footnote.reference>5</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1311" subref="(a)" pararef="(1)">N-PCL &sect;1311(a)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> A foreign corporation&apos;s authority to conduct activities in the State of New York terminates on the filing by the Department of State of the certificate of surrender of authority.<footnote><footnote.reference>6</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1311" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;1311(c)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The procedures for the voluntary, nonjudicial dissolution and the application and distribution of assets of a not-for-profit corporation are set forth in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.<footnote><footnote.reference>7</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1001 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;1001 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The Law also sets forth what must be contained in the certificate of dissolution, which must be signed and delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.reference>8</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1003">N-PCL &sect;1003</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Certificate of dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1332">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;1332</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>Basically, a nonjudicial dissolution of a not-for-profit corporation must be initiated by the adoption by the corporation&apos;s board of directors of a plan for its dissolution and the distribution of its assets.<footnote><footnote.reference>9</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1001">N-PCL &sect;1001</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> This plan must implement any provision in the certificate of incorporation prescribing the distributive rights of its members.<footnote><footnote.reference>10</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1001" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;1001(a)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<feature.para.block><name.block><name>Practice Tip:</name></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>If the corporation is a charitable corporation and has no assets to distribute and no liabilities at the time of dissolution, the plan must include a statement to that effect.<footnote><footnote.reference>11</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1001" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;1001(b)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> If the corporation has no assets to distribute, other than a reserve not to exceed &dollar;25,000 for the purpose of paying ordinary and necessary expenses of winding up its affairs including attorney and accountant fees, and liabilities not in excess of &dollar;10,000 at the time of adoption of the plan of dissolution, the plan of dissolution must include a statement to that effect.<footnote><footnote.reference>12</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1001" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;1001(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</feature.para.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The board must then submit its plan to the members of the corporation for approval.<footnote><footnote.reference>13</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1002" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;1002(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The dissolution is deemed authorized when the plan is approved by the statutory two-thirds vote of the members, provided, however, that if the corporation is a charitable corporation, other than a corporation incorporated pursuant to the article governing public cemetery corporations, the vote required by the corporation&apos;s board of directors for adoption of the plan of dissolution of such a corporation or by the corporation&apos;s members for the authorization thereof will be:</para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>(1)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>In the case of a vote by the board of directors: (i) the number of directors required under the certificate of incorporation, bylaws, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law and any other applicable law; (ii) two-thirds of the directors present at the time of the vote, if a quorum is present at that time; or (iii) if the number of directors actually holding office as such at the time of the vote to adopt the plan is less than the number required to constitute a quorum of directors under the certificate of incorporation, the bylaws, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or any other applicable law, the remaining directors unanimously;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>(2)</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>In the case of a vote by the members, (i) the number of members required under the certificate of incorporation, bylaws, the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law and any other applicable law; or (ii) by the vote of members authorized by an order of the Supreme Court pursuant to <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="608">N-PCL &sect;608</cite> permitting the corporation to dispense with the applicable quorum requirement.<footnote><footnote.reference>14</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1002" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;1002(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>Notice of a special or regular meeting of the board of directors or of the members entitled to vote on adoption and authorization or approval of the plan of dissolution must be sent to all the directors and members of record entitled to vote. Unless otherwise directed by order of the Supreme Court pursuant to <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="608">N-PCL &sect;608</cite>, the notice must be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last-known address of record of each director and member not fewer than 30, and not more than 60 days before the date of each meeting provided, however, that if the last-known address of record of any director or member is not within the United States, the notice to such director will be sent by any other reasonable means.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>If there are no members entitled to vote on the dissolution of the corporation, the plan of dissolution and distribution of assets will be deemed authorized upon its adoption by the board.<footnote><footnote.reference>15</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1002" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;1002(b)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> However, the plan must also be approved by any governmental body or officer whose approval was required for the formation of the corporation.<footnote><footnote.reference>16</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1002" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;1002(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Moreover, approval of the attorney general also is required for a charitable corporation or for any noncharitable corporation that holds assets at the time of dissolution legally required to be used for a particular purpose.<footnote><footnote.reference>17</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1002" subref="(d)" pararef="(1)">N-PCL &sect;1002(d)(1)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote> Application to the attorney general for such approval is by verified petition, with the plan of dissolution and distribution of assets and certified copies of the consents prescribed by law annexed thereto.<footnote><footnote.reference>18</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1002" subref="(d)" pararef="(2)">N-PCL &sect;1002(d)(2)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>After the plan of dissolution and distribution of assets has been adopted, authorized, approved and carried out pursuant to the terms of the plan within the time period set forth pursuant to statute, a certificate of dissolution, entitled &ldquo;Certificate of Dissolution of (Name of Corporation) Under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1003">Section 1003 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law</cite>,&rdquo; and containing the information required by the statute must be signed and, if required by statute, after the Attorney General has affixed thereon his or her consent to the dissolution, delivered to the Department of State.<footnote><footnote.reference>19</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1003" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;1003(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The certificate must set forth the following information:</para.text>
<list list.style="para">
<list.item><name.block><designator>a</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The corporation&apos;s name and, if its name has been changed, the name under which it was formed;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>b</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The date its certificate of incorporation was filed by the Department of State;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>c</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The name and address of each of its officers and directors;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>d</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>A statement as to whether the corporation is a charitable corporation or a noncharitable corporation;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>e</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>A statement as to whether or not the corporation holds assets at the time of dissolution, which are legally required to be used for a particular purpose;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>f</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>That the corporation elects to dissolve;</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>g</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>The manner in which the dissolution was authorized; and</para.text></para></list.item>
<list.item><name.block><designator>h</designator></name.block><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>A statement that, prior to delivery of such certificate of dissolution to the Department of State for filing, the plan of dissolution and distribution of assets has been approved by the Attorney General or a justice of the supreme court, if such approval is required. A copy of the approval of the attorney general or of the court order must be attached to the certificate of dissolution. In the case of a corporation, other than a corporation incorporated pursuant to the article governing public cemetery corporations, that has no assets to distribute, or has no assets to distribute other than a reserve not to exceed &dollar;25,000 for the purpose of paying ordinary and necessary expenses of winding up its affairs including attorney and accountant fees, and liabilities not in excess of &dollar;10,000 at the time of dissolution, a statement that a copy of the plan of dissolution that contains the statement prescribed by statute has been duly filed with the Attorney General, if required.<footnote><footnote.reference>20</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1003" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;1003(a)</cite>.</para.text></para></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para></list.item>
</list></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text>If Attorney General approval or approval by a governmental body or officer of the dissolution is required, such approval must be endorsed on or annexed to the certificate.<footnote><footnote.reference>21</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1003" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;1003(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Nonjudicial dissolution of not-for-profit corporation, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> The Law further provides that the Department of State may not file the certificate of dissolution unless the consent of the State Department of Taxation and Finance to the dissolution is attached to the certificate.<footnote><footnote.reference>22</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1004">N-PCL &sect;1004</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Certificate of dissolution, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote> Upon filing the certificate, the corporation is then dissolved.<footnote><footnote.reference>23</footnote.reference><footnote.body><para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|56|30:52"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="1004">N-PCL &sect;1004</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr4" titlename="Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club" volref="70" pageref="897">Right to assets of voluntarily dissolved lodge or club, 70 A.L.R.4th 897</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text>Certificate of dissolution, <cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1328 to 1336" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1328 to 1336</cite>.</ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block></footnote.body></footnote></para.text></para>
</section.body>
</section>
</section.block>

<outline.name.block>
<designator>2</designator><name>Checklists</name></outline.name.block>
