Substantially all its activities must be for the purposes for which it was organized. Clubs engaging in an unrelated business run the risk of losing exempt status. No more than 35&percnt; of a club&apos;s gross income can come from investment sources or from nonmembership sources. Furthermore, no more than 15&percnt; of a club&apos;s gross income can come from use of a club&apos;s facilities by the public. None of the earnings of a club can inure to the benefit of a private shareholder.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>An exempt club is subject to one special requirement: Neither the charter nor bylaws, nor any written policy of the club, can provide for discrimination against any person on the basis of race, color or religion. Two exceptions exist: (1) a club can discriminate on religious grounds if it limits its membership to a particular religion in order to further the principles of that religion. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(i)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;501(i)</cite>; or (2) an auxiliary of a fraternal benefit society that limits its membership to those of a particular religion may also discriminate on religious grounds.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>A qualified social club is exempt from tax only on income from its exempt activities, that is, from amounts paid by its members. Investment income is taxed, as is all other unrelated business income. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="501" subref="(b)">26 U.S.C.A. &dblsect;501(b)</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="512">512</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Dues, fees, assessments, and similar payments made to a social or recreational club are not deductible. This applies whether the club is used for personal purposes (<cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="262">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;262</cite>) or business purposes. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="274" subref="(a)" pararef="(3)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;274(a)(3)</cite>. This is an exception to the general rule that ordinary and reasonable expenses incurred in connection with the operation of a business are deductible. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="162" subref="(a)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;162(a)</cite>. The prohibition applies to clubs organized for &ldquo;business, pleasure, recreation, or other social purpose.&rdquo; It applies even to clubs used solely for the benefit of employees. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="274" subref="(e)" pararef="(4)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;274(e)(4)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>A possible exception may exist for payments to &ldquo;clubs&rdquo; that are really associations directly organized for the furtherance of a business purpose. If such an association does not offer the customary amenities of a club&mdash;dining and recreational facilities&mdash;the costs should be deductible as business expenses.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Contributions to a club do not qualify as deductible donations for income tax purposes. An exception may also exist here if the organization is not really a social or recreational club but is devoted to some purpose for which a charitable contribution is permitted under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="170" subref="(b)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;170(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The situation under the estate tax is less categorical. Only contributions for public, religious, charitable, scientific, literary, educational and certain other purposes are deductible. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-code" titleref="26" secref="2055" subref="(a)">26 U.S.C.A. &sect;2055(a)</cite>. While this would seem to exclude contributions to most clubs, a bequest to trustees of a club to give financial assistance to the sick and unfortunate residents of a town was held deductible, as was a contribution to an art club devoted principally to educational activities. In the latter case the club also provided incidental social activities, but this did not prevent the contribution from being deductible.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Bylaws, see <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="602">N-PCL &sect;602</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>As to contents of bylaws, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:44">&sect;30:44</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>As to adoption of bylaws, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:45">&sect;30:45</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>For pertinent checklist concerning matters that may be covered in bylaws, see <cite type="secondaryxref" secref="30:56">&sect;30:56</cite>.</para.text></para>
</note.group>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="topic.key" normalpub="key" sub="Corporations and Business Organizations" numref="3384">West&apos;s Key Number Digest, Corporations and Business Organizations &key;3384</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
<item.reference.block>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>1.01.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="402" subref="(a)" pararef="(3)">Not-for-Profit Corporation Law &sect;402(a)(3)</cite> requires that the Certificate of Incorporation set forth the county within the State of New York in which the office of the corporation is to be located. The certificate may also set forth the post office address of an office without the state at which, pursuant to <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="621">N-PCL &sect;621</cite>, the books and records of the corporation shall be kept. Accordingly, this bylaw provision is optional but may be useful in that the board of directors is authorized to determine from time to time whether other offices within or outside the State of New York are necessary or desirable.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.01.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>A not-for-profit corporation may have one or more classes of members or, in the case of a charitable corporation, may have no members. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;601(a)</cite>. If a corporation has two or more classes of members, the designation of each class and the qualifications and rights of, and limitations upon, the members of each class may be set forth in the certificate of incorporation, the bylaws or, if the bylaws so provide, a resolution of the board of directors. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;601(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>If the corporation has members, membership may be effected and evidenced by: (1) signature on the certificate of incorporation; (2) designation in the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws; (3) membership certificate or card or capital certificate; or (4) such method, including, but not limited to the foregoing, as is prescribed by the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;601(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="823">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;823</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.02.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Membership is not generally transferable unless otherwise specified in the certificate of incorporation or bylaws. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(d)">N-PCL &sect;601(d)</cite>.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.03.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The annual meeting of members may be held at any time during the year. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="603" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;603(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="908">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;908</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.04.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="603" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;603(c)</cite> provides that special meetings may be called by the board of directors and by such person or persons as may be authorized by the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws. In any case, special meetings may be convened by members entitled to cast 10&percnt; of the total number of votes entitled to be cast at such meeting. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="605" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;605(a)</cite> sets forth specific provisions to be included in the notice of special meetings.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="897">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;897</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.05.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="611">N-PCL &sect;611</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="902">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;902</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.06.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="605" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;605(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>In the event that the corporation has more than 500 members, the notice may be served by publication in a newspaper published in the county in the state in which the principal office of the corporation is located, once a week for three successive weeks next preceding the date of the meeting, provided that the corporation shall also prominently post notice of such meeting on the homepage of any website maintained by the corporation continuously from the date of publication through the date of the meeting. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="605">N-PCL &sect;605</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Written notice must state the place, date and hour of the meeting, the means of electronic communication, if any, by which members may participate in the proceedings of the meeting and, unless it is an annual meeting, indicate that it is being issued by or at the direction of the person or persons calling the meeting. Notice of a special meeting must also state the purpose or purposes for which the meeting is called. A copy of the notice of any meeting must be given, personally, by mail, or by facsimile telecommunications or by electronic mail, to each member entitled to vote at such meeting. If the notice is given personally, by first class mail or by facsimile telecommunications or by electronic mail, it must be given not less than 10 nor more than 50 days before the date of the meeting; if mailed by any other class of mail, it must be given not less than 30 nor more than 60 days before such date. If mailed, such notice is given when deposited in the United States mail, with postage thereon prepaid, directed to the member at his or her address as it appears on the record of members, or, if he or she has filed with the secretary of the corporation a written request that notices to him or her be mailed to some other address, then directed to him of her at such other address. If sent by facsimile telecommunication or mailed electronically, such notice is given when directed to the member&apos;s fax number or electronic mail address as it appears on the record of members, or, to such fax number or other electronic mail address as filed with the secretary of the corporation. Notwithstanding the foregoing, such notice shall not be deemed to have been given electronically (1) if the corporation is unable to deliver two consecutive notices to the member by facsimile telecommunication or electronic mail; or (2) the corporation otherwise becomes aware that notice cannot be delivered to the member by facsimile telecommunication or electronic mail. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="605" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;605(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Notice of a meeting need not be given to any member who submits a waiver of the notice, in person or by proxy, whether before or after the meeting. Waiver of notice may be written or electronic. If written, the waiver must be executed by the member or the member&apos;s authorized officer, director, employee, or agent by signing such waiver or causing his or her signature to be affixed to such waiver by any reasonable means, including, but not limited to facsimile signature. If electronic, the transmission of the waiver must be sent by electronic mail and set forth, or be submitted with, information from which it can reasonably be determined that the transmission was authorized by the member. The attendance of any member at a meeting, in person or by proxy, without protesting prior to the conclusion of the meeting the lack of notice of the meeting, shall constitute a waiver of notice by that member. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="606">N-PCL &sect;606</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="901 to 907" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;901 to 907</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.07.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Notice of a meeting need not be given to any member who submits a waiver of the notice, in person or by proxy, whether before or after the meeting. Waiver of notice may be written or electronic. If written, the waiver must be executed by the member or the member&apos;s authorized officer, director, employee, or agent by signing such waiver or causing his or her signature to be affixed to such waiver by any reasonable means, including, but not limited to facsimile signature. If electronic, the transmission of the waiver must be sent by electronic mail and set forth, or be submitted with, information from which it can reasonably be determined that the transmission was authorized by the member. The attendance of any member at a meeting, in person or by proxy, without protesting prior to the conclusion of the meeting the lack of notice of the meeting, shall constitute a waiver of notice by that member. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="606">N-PCL &sect;606</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="901 to 907" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;901 to 907</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.08.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="607">N-PCL &sect;607</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="933">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;933</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.09.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Members entitled to cast a majority of the total number of votes at a meeting will constitute a quorum at the meeting, provided that when a specified item of business is required to be voted on by a class of members, voting as a class, members entitled to cast a majority of the total votes entitled to be cast by such class will constitute a quorum for the transaction of such specified items of business. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="608" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;608(a)</cite>. The certificate of incorporation or the bylaws may provide for any lesser quorum not less than the members entitled to cast 100 votes or one-tenth of the total number of votes entitled to be cast, whichever is lesser, and may, under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="615">N-PCL &sect;615</cite>, provide for a greater quorum. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="608" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;608(b)</cite>. The members present may adjourn the meeting despite the absence of a quorum. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="608" subref="(d)">N-PCL &sect;608(d)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="912">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;912</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.10.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>There is no applicable section in the statute. This provision reflects standard corporate practice.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.11.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="609">N-PCL &sect;609</cite> provides that members may vote by proxy unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation or bylaws.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="943 to 946" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;943 to 946</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.12.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>This set of bylaws provides that inspectors are not required unless expressly requested by a member present in person or by proxy at a meeting.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="610">N-PCL &sect;610</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="926, 927" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;926, 927</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.13.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Other optional provisions concerning members&apos; votes may be set forth in the certificate of incorporation or bylaws. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="601" subref="(a), (b)">N-PCL &dblsect;601(a), (b)</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="612">612</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="615 to 617" secrange="y">615 to 617</cite> (if adopted by members).</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="611">N-PCL &dblsect;611</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="613">613</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="544, 931" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;544, 931</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>2.14.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>If the written consent of fewer than all of the members is authorized, such provision must be included in the certificate of incorporation. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="614">N-PCL &sect;614</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="602">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;602</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>ARTICLE</label><designator>III.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Not-for-profit corporations frequently refer to directors as &ldquo;trustees,&rdquo; and this term may be substituted for &ldquo;directors&rdquo; throughout this form.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.01.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation, a corporation shall be managed by its board of directors. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="701">N-PCL &sect;701</cite>. Each director must be at least 18 years old. Note specific provisions concerning certain not-for-profit corporations in <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="701">N-PCL &sect;701</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="535">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;535</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.02.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Although not expressly provided by statute, apparently a variable range of the number of directors is permitted. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="702">N-PCL &sect;702</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The minimum number of directors of a not-for-profit corporation is set by statute at three. Subject to such limitation, the number may be fixed by the bylaws or, in the case of a corporation having members, by action of the members or the board under the specific provisions of a bylaw adopted by the members. If not otherwise fixed, the number shall be three. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="702" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;702(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="537">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;537</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.03.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Directors may be elected for staggered terms. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="704">N-PCL &sect;704</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The certificate of incorporation or a bylaw adopted by the members may provide that directors, elected or appointed at large, shall be divided into either two, three, four, or five classes for the purpose of staggering their terms of office and that all or some of the directors elected or appointed otherwise than at large shall be divided into the same or a different number of classes, not exceeding five, for the same purpose. All classes shall be as nearly equal in number as possible and, if provision has been made for cumulative voting, no class shall include less than three directors. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="704" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;704(a)</cite>. The terms of office of the directors initially classified shall be as follows: that of the first class shall expire at the next annual meeting of members if there be members or of the board if there be no members; the second class at the second succeeding annual meeting; the third class, if any, at the third annual meeting, and so on. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="704" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;704(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="541">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;541</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.04.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="705">N-PCL &dblsect;705</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="704">704</cite>.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.05.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>There is no provision. But see <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="602" subref="(f)">N-PCL &sect;602(f)</cite>, which provides that the bylaws may contain any provision relating to the new powers or rights of the corporation&apos;s directors not inconsistent with New York law or the certificate of incorporation.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="552 to 554" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;552 to 554</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.06.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corp. Law provides that any or all of the directors may be removed for cause by vote of the directors, provided there is a quorum of not less than a majority present at the meeting of directors at which such action is taken. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="706" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;706(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="563 to 565" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;563 to 565</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.07.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="708">N-PCL &dblsect;708</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="710">710</cite>, and <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="711">711</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Regular meetings of the board of directors may be held without notice if the time and place of such meetings are fixed by the bylaws. Special meetings of the board of directors must be held on notice to the directors. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="711" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;711(a)</cite>. Notice of a meeting need not be given to any alternate director nor to any director who submits a waiver of notice, whether before or after the meeting, or who attends the meeting without protesting, prior to such meeting or at its commencement, the lack of notice to such director. Such waiver of notice may be written or electronic. If written, the waiver must be executed by the director signing such waiver or causing his or her signature to be affixed to such waiver by any reasonable means including but not limited to facsimile signature. If electronic, the transmission of the waiver must be sent by electronic mail and set forth, or be submitted with, information from which it can reasonably be determined that the transmission was authorized by the director. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="711" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;711(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The bylaws may prescribe what will constitute notice of a meeting of the board. A notice or waiver of notice need not specify the purpose of any regular or special meeting of the board unless required by the bylaws. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="711" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;711(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="595 to 607" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;595 to 607</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.08.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Unless otherwise provided in the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws, a majority of the entire board of directors constitutes a quorum, provided that the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws may fix the quorum at less than a majority of the entire board if, in the case of a board of 15 members or less, the quorum is at least one-third of the entire number of members, and in the case of a board of more than 15 members, the quorum must be at least five members plus one additional member for every 10 members (or fraction thereof) in excess of 15. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="707">N-PCL &sect;707</cite>. See also <cite type="case">Desuzia v. Board of Directors of Concourse Village, Inc., 117 A.D.3d 426, 985 N.Y.S.2d 48 (1st Dep&apos;t 2014)</cite>, stating that a supermajority quorum requirement may be imposed through corporate bylaws.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The act of a majority of the directors present at a meeting at which a quorum is present will be the act of the board of directors unless the act of a greater number is required by the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="708" subref="(d)">N-PCL &sect;708(d)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="605">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;605</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.09.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Provision is made in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law for informal action by directors. Unless otherwise restricted by the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws, any action required or permitted to be taken by the board or any committee thereof may be taken without a meeting if all members of the board or the committee consent to the adoption of a resolution authorizing the action. Such consent may be written or electronic. If written, the consent must be executed by the director by signing such consent or causing his or her signature to be affixed to such consent by any reasonable means including, but not limited to, facsimile signature. If electronic, the transmission of the consent must be sent by electronic mail or other electronic means and set forth, or be submitted with, information from which it can reasonably be determined that the transmission was authorized by the director. The resolution and the written consents thereto by the members of the board or committee shall be filed with the minutes of the proceedings of the board or committee. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="708" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;708(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Unless otherwise restricted by the certificate of incorporation or the bylaws, any one or more members of the board or of any committee thereof who is not physically present at a meeting of the board or a committee may participate by means of a conference telephone or similar communications equipment or by electronic video screen communication. Participation by such means will constitute presence in person at a meeting as long as all persons participating in the meeting can hear each other at the same time and each director can participate in all matters before the board, including, without limitation, the ability to propose, object to, and vote upon a specific action to be taken by the board or committee. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="708" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;708(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="602">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;602</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.10.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Both a short and long form for this section is provided, in the event that practitioners may wish to include the specific statutory limitations on the authority committees may exercise.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The certificate of incorporation, the bylaws, or the board may create committees of the board, each consisting of three or more directors. The board will appoint the members of such committee of the board, except that in the case of any executive committee or similar committee however denominated, the appointment will be made by a majority of the entire board, provided that in the case of a board of 30 members or more, the appointment will be made by at least three-quarters of the directors present at the time of the vote, if a quorum is present at that time. In addition, the bylaws may provide that directors who are the holders of certain positions in the corporation must be ex-officio members of specific committees. To the extent provided in the resolution or in the certificate of incorporation or in the bylaws, each committee will have and may exercise all the authority of the board, with certain important exceptions enumerated in the N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="712" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;712(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="592 to 594" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;592 to 594</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.11.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>A corporation may pay reasonable compensation to its members, directors, and officers for services rendered. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="515" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;515(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Payment of premiums by corporation on corporate officer&apos;s life insurance policy as affecting right to policy" volref="56" pageref="1086">Payment of premiums by corporation on corporate officer&apos;s life insurance policy as affecting right to policy, 56 A.L.R.3d 1086</cite> (secs. 3(a), 3(b) superseded in part by <cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr7" titlename="Construction and Application of &ldquo;Key Man&rdquo; Life Insurance" volref="12" pageref="Art. 6">Construction and Application of &ldquo;Key Man&rdquo; Life Insurance, 12 A.L.R.7th Art. 6</cite>).</ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr3" titlename="Test in stockholders&apos; actions as to reasonableness of compensation of corporate officers who as directors determine own compensation" volref="53" pageref="358">Test in stockholders&apos; actions as to reasonableness of compensation of corporate officers who as directors determine own compensation, 53 A.L.R.3d 358</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="789, 791" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;789, 791</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="ajpof2" titlename="Reasonableness of Corporate Officer&apos;s Compensation" volref="4" pageref="425">Reasonableness of Corporate Officer&apos;s Compensation, 4 Am. Jur. Proof of Facts 2d 425</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.12.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The board of directors of a not-for-profit corporation is required by the statute to present at the annual meeting of the members of the corporation a report, verified by the President and treasurer or by a majority of the directors or certified by an independent public or certified public accountant or a firm of such accountants selected by the board. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="519">N-PCL &sect;519</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The board of directors of not-for-profit corporations that have no members must direct the President and treasurer to present an annual report pursuant to provisions of <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="519" subref="(c)">N-PCL &sect;519(c)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="alr5" titlename="&ldquo;Responsible Corporate Officer&rdquo; Doctrine or &ldquo;Responsible Relationship&rdquo; of Corporate Officer to Corporate Violation of Law" volref="119" pageref="205">&ldquo;Responsible Corporate Officer&rdquo; Doctrine or &ldquo;Responsible Relationship&rdquo; of Corporate Officer to Corporate Violation of Law, 119 A.L.R.5th 205</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="378">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;378</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>3.13.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>The N.Y. Not-for-Profit Corporation Law provides that the sale, mortgage, or lease of real property of the corporation must be authorized by a vote of two-thirds of the entire board of directors, provided that if there are 21 or more directors, the vote of a majority of the entire board is sufficient. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="509">N-PCL &sect;509</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="1267 to 1271" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;1267 to 1271</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>4.01.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text><cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="713" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;713(b)</cite> provides that the certificate of incorporation or a bylaw adopted by the members may provide that all or specific officers shall be elected by the members rather than the board. Alternatively, such provision may authorize the President to appoint other officers (or some of them), subject to approval by the board. Under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="713" subref="(d)">N-PCL &sect;713(d)</cite>, the certificate or bylaws may provide that any one or more officers shall be ex-officio members of the board, with voting rights unless otherwise specified. Consider whether inclusion of such provisions in the certificate or in a bylaw adopted by the members is relevant. See also <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="714" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;714(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="531">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &sect;531</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>4.02.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Officers may be elected by the members if the certificate of incorporation or bylaw adopted by the members so provides. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="713" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;713(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Note that under <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="714" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;714(a)</cite>, the removal power of the board should not extend to officers elected or appointed by the members or by a class of members. The board may, however, suspend these officers for cause.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Any officer elected or appointed by the board may be removed by the board with or without cause. An officer elected by the members may be removed, with or without cause, only by vote of the members, but the authority to act as an officer may be suspended by the board for cause. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="714" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;714(a)</cite>. The removal will be without prejudice to the contract rights, if any, of the person so removed. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="714" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;714(b)</cite>. Election or appointment of an officer will not of itself create any contract rights. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="714" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;714(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="714">N-PCL &sect;714</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="566 to 568" secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;566 to 568</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>4.03.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Alternate provisions are supplied if a detailed description of the powers and duties relevant to each office is desired.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>
<reference.entry><ref.text><cite type="secondary" normalpub="nyj2" topicname="Business Relationships" secref="683 et seq." secrange="y">N.Y. Jur. 2d, Business Relationships &dblsect;683 et seq.</cite></ref.text></reference.entry>
</research.reference.block>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>4.05.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="202">N-PCL &dblsect;202</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="515">515</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="715">715</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>A corporation may pay reasonable compensation to its members, directors, and officers for services rendered. See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="515" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;515(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>As to indemnification of officers, directors, employees, and agents, as well as insurance, see <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="721 et seq." secrange="y">N-PCL &dblsect;721 et seq.</cite></para.text></para>

<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>5.02.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>See <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="107">N-PCL &dblsect;107</cite>, <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="202" subref="(a)" pararef="(3)">202(a)(3)</cite>.</para.text></para>
</item.reference>
<item.reference><name.block><label>Section</label><designator>5.04.</designator></name.block>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Every not-for-profit corporation is required to keep, at the office of the corporation, correct and complete books and records of account and minutes of the proceedings of its members, board, and executive committee, if any, and must keep at such office or at the office of its transfer agent or registrar in this state a list or record containing the names and addresses of all members, the class or classes of membership or capital certificates and the number of capital certificates held by each, and the dates when they respectively became the holders of record thereof. A corporation may keep its books and records of account in an office of the corporation without the state, as specified in its certificate of incorporation. Any of the foregoing books, minutes, and records may be in written form or in any other form capable of being converted into written form within a reasonable time. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="621" subref="(a)">N-PCL &sect;621(a)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<para ct.id="f2fd26a0b92511efa75bc0a5c2da1858|106|30:98"><para.text>Any person who has been a member of record of a corporation for at least six months immediately preceding his or her demand, or any person holding, or thereunto authorized in writing by the holders of, at least 5&percnt; of any class of the outstanding capital certificates, upon at least five-days written demand shall have the right to examine in person or by agent or attorney, during usual business hours, its minutes of the proceedings of its members and list or record of members and to make extracts therefrom. <cite type="lrre" normalpub="statute-us-ny-law-notforprofitcorp" secref="621" subref="(b)">N-PCL &sect;621(b)</cite>.</para.text></para>
<research.reference.block>

Fed. 177</cite>).</ref.text></reference.entry>
